text:
I make these every year around the holidays - people love them.  Do not store them in an airtight container though - they have a lot of moisture from the pumpkin and get moist and mushy.  They stay great out on the counter for days.  Delicious w/ coffee!

text:
These cookies are superb. Soft and cakelike, not at all dense or sticky. The take on a beautiful shape while baking. I replaced 1/2 cup of the white sugar with light brown sugar and used 1 1/2 teaspoons of cinnamon and 1 1/2 teaspoons of pumpkin pie spice instead of the spices listed (what I happened to have on hand). Try adding a little cinnamon to the icing--it looks beautiful. So good! Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Years ago I gave this wonderful recipe to a former friend of mine who owns a chain of 17 deli-restaurants in our area. Customers LOVE this cake-like cookie.  It is so popular it is sold year-round. Skip the glaze and use a cream cheese icing instead.  Delicious! *****UPDATE 2011***** Apparently these are THE most popular cookies sold in this business and they sell out daily.  If anyone is wondering, the initials of this business are "C.B" and it is located in the mid-south.

text:
This recipe is very good.  However, I needed to make a few adjudments.  I followed the recipe exactly and the end product was this: a cookie that was bready and not sweet like a cookie should be.  So for my second batch I added more pumpkin and more sugar and decreased the baking time to 12 minutes. Also, since I'm not a big fan of icing on cookies, I ommitted the icing.  Viola!  A perfect pumpkin spice cookie =)

region:

country:
None
text:
These cookies are very good,...soft, fluffy, moist, subtle spices, and just enough pumpkin flavor. Texture was similar to a muffin top.  I was attempting to get a denser consistency, so I baked the cookies for only about 12 min and substituted 1/2 of the white sugar with brown. Also, I used almost the whole 15oz can of pumpkin puree, which made the dough stickier to work with, but the end product still tasted great (although not dense like I was hoping).  I uploaded 2 photos of the finished cookie, iced and not iced. For the iced ones, I dropped 1 tablespoon of the mixture and lightly flattened them. No spreading whatsoever...even the little "peaks" from dropping onto the sheet remained intact. So for subsequent batches, I smoothed the drops of dough with my fingers. The icing was way too sweet for me. For the un-iced ones, I flattened them with a sugared bottom cup. I liked the un-iced ones better...simple and basic in flavor.

I will be keeping this recipe, sharing it with friends and making them throughout the year.  Many, many thanks!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these cookies and they are AWESOME! The first batch, I made according to the recipe and they were good. The second batch I changed up and they were the BEST pumpkin cookies EVER! They tasted like pumpkin pie but better, very moist, super delicious. The changes are as listed: 15 ounce can of pumpkin, 2 1/2 tsp - 3 tsp cinnamon, Added 1/2 tsp all spice, 3/4 cup brown sugar, 3/4 cup white sugar, 1/8 cup corn syrup, Used cream cheese frosting instead of icing listed: 1/2 cup butter, 8 ounce cream cheese, 4 cups powder sugar, 1 tsp vanilla. The rest of recipe stayed the same. I made two batches and the frosting was enough for both so you could cut the icing recipe in half for just one batch. Another helpful hint do not over bake, bake time I used was 12-15 minutes. I started checking them at 12 mins and took out when they started to turn slightly golden brown. These are a Fall must have! Make them and see just how fast they disappear, Enjoy!

FANTASTIC cookies. I went ahead and added the whole 15oz can of pumpkin (instead of just a cup), and added some cinnamon to the glaze and drizzled it over the cookies. They came out perfect. Will be a staple! EDITED: Made these again and froze about half of the already-iced cookies in saran wrap for about 2 weeks. They thaw out very quickly (fridge or countertop), and are just as good as freshly made.

Display Name:
cosmic_me

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you want to surpass all holiday cookies that are served during the season and be the talk of evening at all the gatherings THIS is the cookie recipe to bring.  From Halloween to Christmas your family and friends will be begging for you to bring these.  I've made just the slightest alterations to make these stand out as a signature cookie above all others.  For the recipe itself trust me and go with half white and half brown sugar.  Now split your dough in half.  In one batch add chocolate chips.  In the other batch add chopped nuts.  Walnuts or pecans are the best.  The best way to make these beauties shape perfectly is to use a scoop and then take the back of a wet spoon and smooth the top surface out using a circular motion.  The end result is a beautifully Large shaped incredible cookie.  Now for the best frosting: The ones with the chocolate chips I go with a cream cheese icing.  The compliment of flavors is incredible.  Ad some sprinkles if you'd like.  With the batch that have the nuts go with a maple icing.  Your cookie eaters will go nuts over them.  It's like eating a maple glazed doughnut but this has the complimenting falvor's of pumpkin and maple.   These cookies far surpass those traditional holiday sugar cookies.

text:
These were really yummy, but I do not generally like white frosting... I made caramel glaze instead! Made these into a fall favorite... Just heat 1/2 stick butter (real butter) in small sauce pan until melted and bubbly, add 1.5 cups brown sugar and wisk until bubbling and smells like browned butter, then add 1 Tbs of milk and whisk smooth, let cool a little bit before dunking the tops of your cookies into it. OH SO YUMMY!

userID:
5871681
Display Name:
Nittany Lioness

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies are absolutely wonderful!  I decided to try these for Thanksgiving this year, since the kids don’t like pumpkin pie.  They have a nice spice flavor, and the pumpkin is very subtle.  Unfortunately, they are so addictive that I’ll need to bake another batch before Thursday.  I took the advice of several other reviewers and made some modifications to the recipe.  I used ½ cup packed brown sugar with 1 cup white sugar, and baked the cookies for only 12 minutes.  They came out moist and soft, exactly as I wanted.  If you don’t want cookies with bumps and peaks on top, be sure to smooth over the tops with the back of a spoon before baking.  I added cinnamon to the glaze recipe, and spread the glaze onto the cookie rather than just drizzling.  The cookie itself is not very sweet, but tastes fine without the glaze for those who don’t like frosted cookies.  I left the cookies out on the counter until the glaze hardened a little, then stored them on a plate with a piece of plastic wrap placed loosely on top.  Do not store these in an airtight container.

text:
These combine some of my favorite flavours, pumpkin and spice. They are good as is, but I have since made a more nutritious version, where I substituted applesauce for the butter and added 1 1/2 tbsp of oil as well, used whole wheat flour, and 1 cup of brown sugar, packed, in place of 1 1/2 cups of white, and added 1/2 tsp of ginger. They are still delicious and are healthy enough for my kids lunches.I did not bother icing them, they did not need it.

Unlike some of the others who thought these cookies were too cake-like, I really like the texture of these cookies.  Mine had a crunch to the outside, but the inside was soft and chewy.  Nice flavor on its own, but much better with the icing.  One note...15 min was almost too long to bake.  Definitely not 20 min!  I will definitely make again.

text:
EVERYONE LOVES THESE! I started making them last year to bring to a party and now people are still talking about them. I just made them last week for my husband and I have to limit how many he eats at a time. :) They are great sitting by a fire with friends sipping on Harpoon Winter Warmer (has that cinnamon nutmeg taste as the cookies do) and passing around the pumpkin cookie plate.   The only difficult part, is if your first making them for the first time, the dough is VERY sticky. I have to have a plate of flour next to me and I pat my hands in the flour before I pick up the dough and roll it into a ball. TOALLY worth the mess! Whoever created this recipe is a genius!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious cookies!  I did make some healthier substitutes: I used Splenda instead of sugar, used 2 egg whites instead of 1 egg, added 1 cup unsweetened applesauce, 2 cups canned pumpkin puree and eliminated the flour and used 4 cups oats.  I used a soup spoon to keep size consistent and baked for 12 minutes.  They will be softer because of the applesauce, but hold together nicely when cooled.  For my icing, I used confectioners sugar plus Coffee Mate's coconut cream flavor liquid creamer to add a little flavor to the cookies.  Got rave reviews, especially from my diabetic friends!

Due to the reviews i was really excited to try this being we love pumpkin. First I'd like to say it has wonderful flavor and taste spicey and like pumpkin pie. The reason I'm leaving three stars is it really is not a "cookie" it taste like a pumpkin bread with a glaze over it. I really wanted a cookie not bread. Very soft, very moist and it sticks horribly to your fingers due to the softness. Not what we really wanted and much more simple to just make a pumpkin bread and add the glaze.

text:
My husband, who only raves about desserts that include chocolate and/or peanut butter, really liked these.  They are cakey, not cruchy.  Although I did eat some without the icing, it is the icing that makes these so fantastic.  The two flavors together are a perfect complement, and they come out pretty, too.  I didn't see any need to flatten the dough before baking, but I don't suppose it would hurt them, either.  This one is already on a card in my recipe box so we'll do it again.  Great for bake sales and gifts.

text:
These are like tiny pumpkin cakes - light, fluffy and not too sweet - which is kind of bad because we ate so many!! I baked these on parchment paper lined cookie sheets at 350F for 15 mins. I halved the glaze and added about 1/4 tsp of cinnamon. To avoid a mess, I placed the cooled cookies on the parchment paper I used, poured the glaze in a ziplock bag, cut off a little corner and drizzled the icing. The presentation was beautiful and I'm curious to see what maple extract in the glaze (instead of vanilla) would taste like!

text:
A nice, light cookie, wonderful for fall.   Because it had been described by some as too sweet, I used 1/2 cup white sugar, and 1/2 cup brown sugar.   When I first tried it without the icing, it wasn't quite as sweet as I'd hoped, but with the icing, it was perfect.   (BTW -- I halved the icing recipe, omitting the butter, but keeping the full teaspoon of vanilla.  Worked out beautifully.)  FYI -- With small ping-pong sized ice cream scooper (size 40), the stickiness of the dough is not a problem.  Just scoop and place directly on to a parchment lined cookie sheet.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/114285.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tweaked this recipe based on other reviews, and it turned out AMAZING.  I used a cup of white sugar & 1 cup (not packed) of light brown sugar (I'm glad I did--they still didn't turn out "TOO" sweet this way). I also used the whole can of pumpkin. I substituted mostly whole wheat flour (its all I had in the house), which made them heartier & a little denser (I like the wheatyness).  I also "spilled" in a bit more vanilla, as well as maybe 1/4 tsp orange extract. Mmm!  They turned out very moist & pretty cake-y, and are perfect with milk!  They'd also be nice with chopped pecans in the batter.  I didn't do the icing & they are just fine without it.  Next time I'll try dusting them with powdered sugar before baking.  Also, they spread minimally in the oven, and you may want to smooth over the peaks in the dough with a clean finger prior to baking for a less "rustic" looking cookie.

country:
None
text:
I read a lot of the reviews before trying it, so I tried it with some revisions:
1) swap 1/2 of the white sugar for brown sugar. 
2) add an extra egg. 
3) use a full 15 oz can of pumpkin puree instead of just 1 cup. 
4) add a couple dashes of ginger and a couple extra dashes of cinnamon. 
5) leave off the icing.
6) Make sure cookie sheets are greased - the recipe does not state this.
7) Bake for between 11-13 minutes only.
BEST PUMPKIN COOKIES EVER.

None
text:
Great recipe and easy recipe! I followed the directions (baked them for 15 mins) and came out with cake-like cookies that my friends and I enjoyed. 

Helpful tips: If you're out of eggs or want to skip some cholesterol, you can use half a banana and reduce the amount of sugar to 1 1/4 cup. It worked well when I made it this way, and the cookies smelled of pumpkin-banana goodness! For a crunchier taste, don't round off the cookies after dropping them on the baking sheet, as the little "spikes" will harden up and make for greater texture. If you like your cookies round and smooth, roll the tbsp-size dough pieces into a ball before placing them on the baking sheet.

text:
so i got in a cookie mood tonight, and since i made some pumpkin soup yesterday i thought i may try pumpkin cookies for the first time !

i halved the recipe b/c i didnt need 3 dozen cookies for just me.  like one of the others, i did sift 1 cup of the flour and w/ it halved i just put 1/4 cup of regular.   for the sugar(s)  i had to use 3/4 of a cup, so i put 1/4 cup light brown and the rest white, and i used the crisco butter sticks instead of regular butter.   i split up the batches and made about 12 regular cookie style and then decided to try about 12 in my mini muffin tins, and they turned out great, i posted a pic of those, and think i like them better than the regular cookie style.  made a little bit of the frosting, for the mini style, instead of drizzling i let them cool a little bit and just dipped the tops into the frosting.   very good, recipe !!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were very tasty cookies, although to me, they do not have a "cookie" texture; they feel more like a muffin. So, as long as that's what you're expecting, they're wonderful!
After tasting one, I decided to add golden raisins and a little bit of pumpkin pie spice to the dough to add a little more spice...I like a little more flavor.
For the frosting, I really wanted some cream cheese, so I did a cream cheese glaze instead, with 4 oz cream cheese, 1/2 C powdered sugar, 2 Tb soft butter, dash of salt, 1/2 tsp vanilla, 3 Tbsp milk, and 1/4 tsp cinnamon and dash of pumpkin pie spice. I drizzled this over the cookies and they look and taste great! Only problem with it was that the glaze stayed sticky, so I think I'll try to original glaze next time.
Will definitely make again -- a great fall cookie!

text:
This is a good base recipe but it lacks flavor. It needs spices added and the ones called for doubled. The dough is beautiful -- it bakes up like tiny cakes and that alone is worth four stars. I'd follow advice of one reviewer who said to use cream cheese frosting; that would have made these much better. I had to add cinnamon and cloves to the glaze to try and make up for the lacking spice and underwhelming pumpkin flavor of the cookies. With some tweaking, this could be a really great cookie. I dusted mine with orange sugar when done to make it clear it's a pumpkin cookie (as I'm not sure that's evident by taste).

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
UPDATE:  Changed my rating from 4* to 5*.  I made these again with canned pumpkin.  These cookies turn out terrific.  A little sticky to work with, but very easy and quite YUMMY.  I baked for 18 minutes - perfect.  Yielded 4 dozen cookies.  I will definitely be making them again.  ORIGINAL:  Not sure if my four star rating is fair - you decide.  The flavor and end results were great, but I had a little bit of trouble.  I substituted fresh pumpkin (pureed) for the canned and cooked for 14 minutes.  I cooled completely and stored to frost the next day.  When I took them back out in the morning, the bottom of each layer of cookies had stuck to the top of the layer beneath it.  I cleaned them up the best I could, frosted them, tben put them back in the oven at 300 for 10 minutes.  After cooling (again), they were much sturdier, although still cake-like and moist.  When I stored them the second time, I separated each layer with wax paper (duh).  It appears that using fresh pumpkin puree made the dough a little softer.  It is not as dense as the canned.  Nevertheless, they are VERY good now.

These cookies are INCREDIBLE. I had no idea they'd turn out this good. I did as many others suggested and used a little extra pumpkin, used brown sugar for 1/2 cup of the white sugar, and added some cinnamon to the icing. text:
I just made these and they turned out great, not particularly strong in pumpkin flavour. They are more similar to a muffin top with its kind of cakey texture versus a traditional chewy cookie. I did up the amount of spices that I added to the recipe and replaced 1/2 cup of the white sugar with brown sugar. You can easily fit 15 cookies on a sheet because the cookies don't spread that much, they just puff up a little bit which is why you definitely need to press the cookies a little bit before baking. I preferred these with a cream cheese frosting versus the simple glaze from the recipe.

These were a hit at my office this week. My coworker just ate 6 of them and she normally would never do that. Just know that when you mix all the ingredients, the dough is sticky.. but that's normal. It's easier and tastes amazing!

userID:
3006008
Display Name:
AuntB
isPro:
False
followersCount:
8

madeRecipesCount:
34
favoritesCount:
461
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/131.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has been my "Fall" cookie for many years and everyone always loves them ... many requests for the recipe. They are soft and cake-like and great frosted or not ... though, using two and frosting between with your favorite frosting like whoopie pies won't find anyone complaining.  And, if you call them spice cookies instead of pumpkin, even pumpkin dislikers will have a change of heart. A little suggestion for those of you who are having trouble pressing the cookies down ... until this round of cookies, I have never pressed them down and they turn out with a nice appearance just the same ... especially, if you kind of swirl the dough drop a bit when you place on cookie sheet. The dough bakes down nicely and little, peak-like swirls mark the cookie. But, if you prefer to press without sticking, rub a bit of butter on the bottom of a small glass, dip into a bowl of cinnamon sugar and tap the cookie gently and no-stick. A bonus when making these is a deliciously scented home!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7189776.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
What a great recipe! My husband and I both made these together, and decided we didn't want the icing component, so we made the cookies without the icing (per original recipe).

Instead of adding the icing, we lightly pressed a fork into each flattened cookie to form 'grooves'. Then we put a drop of pure maple syrup on each cookie, spread it so it would seep into the grooves. Then we sprinkled each cookie with brown sugar, and baked the cookies for about 18-20 minutes a sheet on parchment paper.

Also, as we did not have nutmeg, we used allspice instead (with cinnamon and cloves), and used baked butternut squash puree instead of pumpkin puree.

Will make these again. Delicious!!!

text:
What a cookie! This is a great recipe for those that are just beginning to bake too, I also substituted 1/2 cup of brown sugar for 1/2 a cup of the white sugar and it came out great! I used all-spice since I didn't have all of the other spices and a teaspoon of cinnamon.  I also added a little bit more salt (I found the batter was a little bit too sweet) so I added a full teaspoon of salt.  I haven't made the glaze yet but am taking the suggestion to add the cinnamon, these would benefit from a tang, and I think a cream cheese frosting would set them off right! They are so delicious and moist! Thanks for sharing.

text:
These cookies taste good- I made them exactly as the recipe called for. I haven't made any icing for them, though I may eventually. Just be warned, these are a little more like cake than cookies. Not that it's a bad thing. When they bake, they bake in the shape they are. So if you're looking for a nice uniform shape, do it before you bake them (they don't spread like choco chip cookies or such). I did only bake them 12 minutes, as well. Delicious all around!

So spicy and delicious, just the way we like them!! I followed the icing directions exactly, and the icing was super runny would not stay on the cookie.  So instead, I dipped the cookies in the icing and let the excess drip off, let the cookie sit and the icing harden, and then I dipped it again. Mine were not bright orange as shown in the picture, but they sure were delicious!

text:
This is identical to the Old Fashioned Soft Pumpkin Cookies recipe that can be found on the label of Libby's canned pumpkin, with the addition of cloves. I have been making this same recipe (with cloves) for years and it gets rave reviews no matter who tries them. I can't count how many times people have requested the recipe. I strongly recommend using the glaze and baking for only 12-15 minutes. Otherwise, they will be a dry cookie. And for those who rated this recipe really low, make sure you are using canned pumpkin and not pie filling. Maybe that's why you are getting "wet, underbaked middles." This is my kids' favorite cookie year-round. YUMMY!!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-10-31T11:28:08.247
helpfulCount:
3
userID:
3248120
Display Name:
Amy Barber Birkhimer
isPro:
False
followersCount:
10
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
23
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3041607.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these twice and took them to the office I worked at.. both times everyone enjoyed them.  They remind me of Panera Bread's muffie tops, but better.  I agree that it's not a cookie consistensy, but it's still moist inside.  I also made some alterations to the recipe:

Cookie:
I used 1 whole can of pumpkin (small can)
3 tsp of vanilla (1 tbsp)
2 tsp of pumpkin spice (in addition to the other spices)

Icing:
3 tsp of vanilla
Less milk so it was thicker
Sprinkled some cinnamon

I placed the icing in a ziplock baggie like another reviewer suggested and drizzled it on (the second time I made the icing thicker and it spread better and wasn't so watery).  I only cooked them 11-13 minutes.  If you cook them too long they get dry.  I kept them in the frig so the icing would stay solid, but if you plan on serving them the day you make them then I would think it would be fine to leave them out, just don't stack them on top of each other!

I tried semi-sweet chocolate chips in some, gross.  My boyfriend suggested to use milk chocolate next time but I think just adding the chocolate was too much.. they're delicious the way they are!  Also I tried powdered sugar on top instead of icing (to make it more like a PB muffie!) but it didn't take too well.  So original recipe is for me :)

5

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies are incredible!  Tasty, moist, almost melt in your mouth! For the reviewers that think these are too 'cakey', you are probably over baking them.  These cookies it is better to not be sure and underbake them, than to overbake them.  I did not have to mash mine down, they turned out looking like a normal cookie, or a muffin top, if you know what those are.  They are wonderful without any icing drizzled on top, and I debated whether I should even make it, but that is how the recipe is written so I did it. They are still good with the icing, but I don't know if I would bother next time, the cookie can stand on its own.  I'm sure I will make these again!

text:
These are DELICIOUS! They are fluffy and flavorful - they're very much like muffin-tops. Light and fluffy but not cakey. I reccomend using a little extra pumpkin, and maybe brown sugar in lieu of half the white. I also reccomend using CREAM CHEESE frosting instead of the glaze, and you can put toasted pecans on top of the frosting if you like. I even replaced 1/2 cup white flour with white whole wheat and they were delish!  These are a wonderful autumn - or anytime - treat!

Awesome cookies! This is my first review.  Though I'm not a novice cook, I'm a bit out of practice. These were SO easy and wonderful. They turned out perfectly--sort of like muffin tops but with a more tender texture.  The only alteration I made was to  use no butter in the glaze and add cinnamon.  It worked perfectly.  I did only end up with 2 dozen, so I would recommend refrigerating the dough for a few minutes to make small cookies easier.  I was heavyhanded on the  dolloping!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
YUMMY!! This recipe can stand on it's own and it's wonderful.  I like to take recipes and make them my own by changing things up and the changes were fantastic also.  A great base cookie that can be built upon.  I add 1/4 tsp of pumpkin pie spice. I also swapped out 1/2 cup of the white sugar for brown sugar and added 1/4 tsp maple extract to the batter. The dough is kind of sticky but not hard to work with.  I just used my finger to push it off the spoon.  With the glaze I left out the butter and added maple extract and cinnamon.  I drizzled just a very little bit of it over the cookies because my kids found it to sweet if I used a lot.  My 10 year old made me promise not to lose this recipe :)

text:
These cookies are autumn perfection, in looks and taste. I used allspice, pumpkin pie spice, and cinnamon because that's what I had at the time ... but in other batches, I've mixed it up a bit. I find the pumpkin pie spice with the allspice adds a nice depth. I also used turbinado sugar instead of white, which mellowed out the sweetness. I piped the icing on with a plastic bag for an extra festive look!

text:
Let me just add my kudos to all the others.  I made these because my husband swears he does not like pumpkin.  I can understand this seeing that I'm not a big fan of pumpkin pie.  However, these cookies are wonderful!  Perfect texture - between cookie and cake.  And the recipe itself was foolproof.  A very impressive result without a lot of work!  My dough was sticky, so I flattened the cookies with a glass bottom dipped in sugar.  My husband was such a convert that he refused to take any to work. I did take some in to work and everyone wanted the recipe.  I can't wait to make these again as my contribution to Thanksgiving.

text:
More "cake", muffin top actually, than "cookie" but we enjoyed them all the same. Family and friends that prefer chocolate quite like these to their surprise. My adjustments: ginger instead of cloves and 1/2cup of brown sugar substituted for the same amount of white sugar.
They look pretty much the same before and after baking; so, remove any bumps if you'd like a smooth looking cookie. Yes, the sticky batter makes this harder to do - I use an icecream scoop and my fingers

userID:
5470089
Display Name:
NCVE
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
10
favoritesCount:
16
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
SOOO yummy.  I just had three for breakfast because I could not keep my hands off.  I topped them with my own almond / vanilla icing and a large pecan.   I'm including these in some cookie tins I'm gifting.  These are by far my favorite cookie of the 4 types I made. They are soft, moist and fluffy.  They would taste great with a cream cheese frosting too.  The pecan on top was very tasty, I may add pieces all over the top next time.    The cookie had the  PERFECT pumpkin taste.  I chilled the batter about 30 min to make it easier to use.  I practically followed the cookie recipe to the T.  I wouldn't change a thing. 
I'm a cook, not a baker.  I did use 100% pure cane sugar.  Not sure if that makes a difference.  I used All Spice vs nutmeg cloves.  Until now when I googled what it was, I thought it was an ALL inclusive. haha.  The icing I used was a thinner icing. I didn't really want a thick layer.  I used 4TBS butter, 1/4 cup Evaporated milk (heated on stove top together), then added 2c conf. sugar and about 1/2 tsp of Almond and Vanilla extract (to taste really).  ***I'm making these a year later, 4th time in the last month.  Everyone loves them.  I frost them with cream cheese icing and top with pecan pieces.  My next attempt will be to add a little Mexican chocolate to the mix.

Very nice, cakey cookie - not overly sweet (which suits me just fine!). I also like the way they hold their shape & don't spread out all over the cookie sheet!  I did make a couple of minor changes: used 1 cup brown sugar + 1/2 cup white, used 3tsp pumpkin pie spice plus some extra cinnamon & nutmeg (sorry, I can't say how much - just eyeballed it :-),  added 1cup Craisins, and halved the icing recipe (as recommended by another reviewer). text:
I have made these twice. The first time I followed the recipe pretty closely except for adding a half teaspoon of ginger and cutting the cloves back to 1/4 teaspoon.  They were good, but icing them was a hassle, and they didn't store well, the icing would stick to the other cookies if you stacked them at all.  So, in order to see if I could make them easier to store and send, instead of icing, I added a package of white chocolate chips to the dough.  Wow, they are really good that way and much less work.  Husband and son liked them better with the white choc chips, and they loved them with the icing.  Best pumpkin cookies I have found, soft and cakey, while retaining their cookie shape.

text:
What a fantastic fall recipe!  

I made this yesterday and everyone *loved* it.  I adjusted the spices, amped up the cinnamon, added clove, nutmeg, ginger, allspice, and cardamom to round out the flavor.  Added 1/3 brown sugar, 2/3 white sugar.  For the icing, I went light on the vanilla and instead added a hint of orange extract.  I heated the glaze up in the microwave to drizzle it better, which let it harden up into the perfect consistency.

My house still smells like pumpkin spicey goodness!

country:
None
text:
Here's a tip for smoother tops and a more even bake. Dip your fingers in water so they're just barely wet (you don't want puddles on your cookies) and slightly flatten the blobs of cookie dough before you put them in the oven. I tried using the back of a spoon, a glass sprayed with cooking spray, etc. but water worked the best. This gives them a nice, smooth appearance and they aren't as "domed" looking.

I added an extra half teaspoon of cinnamon and a teaspoon of pumpkin pie spice because I like a lot of spice in my pumpkin. I think I could have added even more! I made a cinnamon cream cheese frosting and these were delicious.
Review:

userID:
1780598
Display Name:
mukaikubo

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are pretty good... I've tried them both with just 1 cup of pumpkin, and with the whole 15 oz can (~1.5 cups), and I definitely preferred it with the 1 cup. With the whole can, you need more spices to flavor the pumpkin, and the cookies come out almost too moist to hold the glaze. These cookies don't spread at all - the way they look when you put them on the pan is the way they'll come out of the oven! The dough is sticky right after mixing, so if you want nice flat cookies, give the dough time to rest before making the cookies. This amount of glaze worked well for me with some left over; I dunked the tops of the cookies in it instead of drizzling with a fork. And these definitely need frosting, they're not quite sweet enough to enjoy by themselves! Overall, a tasty cake-like cookie.

text:
These cookies are FABULOUS! Everyone always raves about them. Seriously - the best. Lately, I've been making a double batch, forming all the cookie dough balls, and then freezing half of them in freezer ziplock baggies. Whenever my husband and I are craving some dessert, or we have a small dinner party, I just throw the frozen dough balls in the oven and we have fresh-out-the-oven awesomeness in 20 minutes!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My kids demanded I make more, instead of bringing them to an event I was going to. :)
-instead of the canned puree, I used fresh puree I had frozen after halloween. 
-I tried the icing recipe, but found it too runny to drizzle nicely, it made blobs that took forever to dry. I substituted for premade icing, and it looked just as nice. 
-the cooking time I cut down to 12 minutes, as I found even 15 mins too long, and they turned out just as good. With 15 mins, they almost burned. But with 12 they were evenly cooked to a nice golden brown. 
-All in all, a very nice cookie, that remind me of muffin tops. Good as a muffin recipe as well.

country:
None
text:
These were such a hit!  I made them for a halloween pumpkin painting party and everyone complimented them, please note that I'm not known for my baking skills so this meant a lot.  My husband even asked me to make a second batch to take to work for his buddies.  

The only negative thing, actually has nothing to do with the taste of the cookie, it's just that you can't really package these or put them in containers to give to people, they're very moist and get super mushy if you put them in a baggie or rubbermaid container.  I put them in a large aluminum pan and lightly put a hard plastic top on it so some moisture could get out but not have the cookies get too hard.

text:
Made These gluten and egg free for my son with allergies.  Used EnerG egg replacer for the one egg and 2.5 cups Bob's all-purpose gluten free flour and 1/4 tsp guar (or xanthem)gum.  Ended up using most of the can of organic pumpkin, and also added white chocolate chips. Omitted the glaze.  Baked for 12 min. in a convection oven.  Good, cake-like pumpkin cookie.  The white chocolate chips was a nice addition. And bonus- finally a nice gluten/egg free recipe for my son!

country:
None
text:
Wow! Over two thousand people can't be wrong! I made this almost exactly as written. What I changed:  I used fresh pumpkin, pureed, I used 3/4 c white sugar, 3/4 c brown sugar, only 1/8 teas of nutmeg (not a huge fan), 1/2 teas of cloves, and 2 1/4 teas of cinnamon. Everything else is as stated. I used a "scooper" to drop onto cookie sheet. It was sticky, but the end result is a perfect cookie. I don't have enough confectioners sugar, so I was going to have to try the cream cheese as others suggested, but these are SOOOOO good by themselves, I'm going to save the trouble and the calories! Thanks for an amazing recipe!

None
text:
Though I am a skilled baker, I've never made pumpkin cookies. These did not disappoint!  They are soft, delicious and perfectly spiced.  I doubled the recipe but not the glaze and, since I don't want to feed my kids an overly sugar-laden cookie, this was a good call.  Instead of covering the whole cookie in icing, which they don't need at all, we just striped and swirled some on the top of each (a perfect job for little ones).  We still had half of the glaze leftover, which just means I have to make another batch of cookies, I guess!  This is a perfect cookie, I wouldn't change a thing!

text:
Amazing.  Just amazing.  I'm always experimenting with different types of cookies, but this is the cookie everyone begs for the most.  I did change the recipe slightly as recommended by other reviews.  I substituted 1/2c brown sugar for 1/2c of the white sugar, I baked the cookies for 12-13 minutes instead of 15, I was far more liberal with my spices (and that includes adding it to the icing), and I drizzled the icing rather than drowning the cookie.  I've already made 3 batches since "pumpkin season" began, and I anticipate baking at least another 3-5 batches before Christmas.  It will be a hit at your Office Christmas party!

text:
These were tasty pumpkin cookies, and a nice change from chocolate chip (our family  usual favorite).  It's a softer cookie but not cakey or chewy.  Tastes a bit like gingerbread. I've made the recipe twice and everyone loves it.   On one batch I tried substituting 1/4 C flour with a mix of wheat germ and bran and they were equally well received.  My son is even going to make a batch for his class party for Halloween!  One piece of advice:  the batter remains soft and sticky even after refrigerating, so after putting a spoonful of dough onto parchment lined pan, use slightly damp fingers to round it and flatten slightly before baking.

No tinned pumpkin here in Australia, so microwaved 300gms pumpkin then allowed to cool. Delicious, soft, cakey cookies. Bit hard to handle raw mix as it is so sticky. My 8 yr old says these will be a new favourite!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4473474.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I’ve made these several times now.  Only change I made was that I wasn’t paying attention and used the whole 15 oz can of pumpkin rather than 1 cup called for, but the cookies still turned out great!  They make wonderfully soft delicious cookies that aren’t overly sweet. The batter is fairly thick and sticky, and the cookies don’t really spread out when baking, so I’ve made these as drop cookies, that I slightly flattened with a cup that I had coated the bottom with sugar, I’ve also just dropped spoonfuls of the batter and then sprinkled a cinnamon sugar blend over the top, and I’ve put the batter into a zip top bag, snipped a wide opening in the corner and piped these out into donut shapes (making sure to pipe thickly). They all still baked in about the same amount of time 12-15 minutes.  I’ve also added chocolate chips to the batter, and those cookies were an even bigger hit! This recipe is definitely a keeper!

I simply adore this recipe...this is my second year making it as a "autumn standard" and its just too good.  I bring my extras from baking to work and my co workers can't get enough of them...I receive endless compliments and everyone always think they are from a bakery!  Almost forgot to mention...the only alteration I make is halving the white sugar and using half brown.  This year I tried a variation and replaced all the pumpkin with chunky no sugar added applesauce and used 3 teaspoons of cinnamon and half of nutmeg for an "apple cinnamon" cookies...they spread a little more because the apple is wetter than pupkin but they are still delicious!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made some slight adjustments:  Used Cinnamon and Cloves.  Used 1 cup pumpkin as stated in recipe.  Added additional 1/3-1/2 c. flower, decreased baking  soda and powder to 3/4 teaspoon to make cookies more dense.  Used 1/2 brown 1/2 white sugar.  IMPORTANT:  To achieve good looking cookies, take the time to hand shape, or used the back of metal spoon to make them look good BEFORE baking.  They will look exactly as you put them in.  Though others complained about appearance, if you do that they will be great TASTING AND LOOKING.  Also, frosted with Cream Cheesey Frosting:  1 8 oz cream cheese, 1/4 buttter (both room temp), 1 tsp vanilla (real).  Cream together fully.  Add 2 1/2 cups SIFTED powdered sugar ~ slowly.  Stop when it is thick, but can still be mixed with mixer.  Let cookies cool thoroughly before frosting.  Store in fridge.  They are divine, a hit with all ages and moist without being too moist.

country:

text:
WOW!!!  These cookies are absolutely DELICIOUS and very easy to make!  They're soft, moist, and full of wonderful spices!  Your whole kitchen will have a pleasant aroma to make it really feel like the fall season.  One of my dearest friends (Gail) is coming to visit tomorrow so I wanted to have a special treat for her, and this recipe did the job!  I just recently started baking as a hobby (so I'm no expert) and if I can make these cookies, then anybody can!  Here's what I did to alter the original recipe:  (1) I added 1/2 teaspoon of pumpkin pie spice, and I combined 3/4 cup brown sugar with 3/4 cup white sugar (instead of 1 1/2 cups of white sugar); (2) I also added some pumpkin pie spice to the glaze; (3) I didn't flatten my cookies because I like the more rounded shape at the top of the cookie; (4) I baked them for 14 minutes (instead of 15-20 minutes) which made them taste more moist.  I was so excited about these cookies that I took pictures of them with some pumpkins in the background!  I will definitely make these cookies again very soon because the batch I baked today will be gone by this weekend!  Thank you to Gina (also my sister's name), who submitted this popular recipe!  My mom (Lety), who doesn't even like pumpkin, enjoyed these cookies.  My husband (Trevor) can't wait to come home from work to try them!  Oh, one more thing...they're AWESOME right out of the oven!  Eat them while they're warm with a cold glass of milk!  This is definitely a comfort food!!!

text:
Absolutely oustanding, texture and flavor - a good way to get your veggies too.  I modified the recipe slightly by halving the butter from 1/2 cup down to 1/4 and substituted 1/4 of unsweetened applesauce.  This brings down the portion fat to 1.75 grams per serving. I would add a pinch of orange essence to the icing to give it a little zip...therefore less sweet.  I also added one or two chocolate chips for decoration. This would be fun for kids -- domino cookies! This cookie recipe is great for Halloween or Christmas! Well done. A hit with me and great for sharing - I gave a tin of cookies away today along with the recipe!  Nessie

I can't tell you how good these are!  I made this recipe as written except I only put in 1/2 tsp ground cloves and that was perfect.  Any more than that and it would have been overpowering.  Everyone that tried these loved them including my picky kids.  I made the glaze that is on the "Pumpkin Cookies V" recipe that has brown sugar in it and OMG it is the best!  I turned the cookies upside down and dipped the tops in the glaze.  These cookies are so soft and moist and they didn't dry out even after being in a sealed container for 3 days.  I now have 3 people asking for the recipe just from the first batch.  These are now one of my favorite cookies.

text:
These cookies are absolutely delicious!!!  If you enjoy them, raisins make a wonderful addition to the recipe.  I stir in 1/2 to 1c after the rest of the ingredients are mixed.  Another change up for this recipe is using brown butter icing:  Brown 6T. butter and let cool till warm.  Add 1 tsp. water and 1 tsp. vanilla.  Add powdered sugar until desired consistency.

Nothing says Fall like pumpkins. These cookies were a hit with my daughter and myself. My husband and son did not care for them, but they also don't like pumpkin pie. country:
None
text:
Just made these and LOVE them!  I am positive they would be perfect as is but I did make the following changes.  I used half a cup brown sugar and the rest white rather than all white.  Also used equivalent (3 tsp) of pumpkin pie spice in place of the individual spices cause honestly, I'm lazy!  I added approx. 1/2 c. chopped pecans which added a nice flavor and crunch to balance the cakiness of the cookie.  Finally for the top, rather than the icing I used a whipped cream cheese frosting from the store.  It was lighter than traditional frosting and added the right amount of sweet.  Personally I love the fact that they are more of a "muffin top" because I frequently have breakfast staff meetings that we bring things to share and these will be perfect with a cup of coffee.  One final thought, to help with the sticky dough, I refrigerated it and used a cookie scoop (looks like mini ice cream scoop) to make them more uniform in size and easier to handle.

I love this recipe so I didn't make any major changes just small tweaks. I sub a 1/2 tsp of pumpkin pie spice for the nutmeg, use 1c brown sugar and 1/2 c white sugar instead of 1 & 1/2 c white, and use 2 tsp vanilla. Instead of icing them I added 1 c of dark chocolate chips into the dough then drizzle with chocolate after completely cooled. My husband and I LOVE the combo of pumpkin and chocolate and these make the most amazing pumpkin chocolate chip cookies. Thank you for this recipe its just great!:)

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/39294.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did make a number of small changes, but have no doubt that the original recipe was just as yummy!  We really enjoyed these, and they kept well for a couple of days before losing their freshness a bit.  As far as changes, I halved the nutmeg and cloves (really don't care for too much spice), and I really felt like it was still plenty fall-spicy.  I cut the white sugar to one cup, and added 1/2 c. brown sugar.  I also added a little cinnamon to the icing as other reviewers suggested, which looked nice.  I drizzled the icing over the cookies, then dipped a few so that the entire top was covered.  In my opinion, you really only need to drizzle it - the cookies are great alone, and the drizzling adds a nice sweet touch.  The ones that were covered were almost too sweet.  Also, you really only need a half batch of icing.  I had tons left!  Lastly, I used a cookie scoop to drop balls of dough onto the sheets, and didn't flatten them at all.  They definitely flattened a bit from their ball shape in the oven, and turned out beautifully.  I guess everyone's experiences are different!  Great recipe, can't wait to make them again!

text:
LOVE THIS RECIPE!!! ~ Even my very picky husband gave his thumbs up!  I did some changes:  like the other reviewer, I substituted 1/2 C of sugar for brown sugar,but cut the regular sugar by 2-3 Tbs (1 cup minus 2-3 Tbs sugar, cos' we don't like our sweets to be TOO sweets), I used a full 15oz can of pumpkin.  For the glaze I added a 3 oz soften cream cheese, cut the confectioner's sugar to just 1 C (so that you can taste the cream cheese and not just sugar).  I also dipped my fingers in water (to prevent sticking) to smooth top of the cookie out before putting it into the oven.  Taste fantastic!  Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
I just made my THIRD batch of these fabulous cookies! I have given them away to friends and brought them to a school event where they were gobbled. One man, an army drill sergeant tough guy, took one bite and said "Who made these!?"
I have been asked for the recipe by everyone. 
I added a tsp of pumpkin pie spice to mine and used only brown sugar and they turned out fabulous.
Thanks to the other reviewers, I was given the heads up to watch out for the stickyness of the dough, so using wet hands, I rolled the dough into balls, flattened with my palms and placed the discs carefully on the cookies sheet. They look MUCH nicer this way. All rouned out and nicely shaped.  A little extra trouble, but worth the pretty results!!
GREAT RECIPE!!  Thanks Gina!

text:
OMG! These are the best! I added extra spices as other reviewers suggested and also added 1 cup of raisins and 1/2 cup chopped walnuts. I also used 1/2 cup of brown sugar in place of the 1/2 cup of white sugar.  I added cinnamon in the glaze also as recommended. I used a cookie scoop and moistened my fingers, dipping them in sugar before lightly pressing them down on the pan.  This kept the dough from sticking to  my fingers as it is very sticky. The little bit of sugar didn't hurt the cookies with the glaze on top.  My husband will definately want these again.

text:
I hate giving ratings of less than 5, but this cookie recipe did not impress me all that much. Like some other reviewers, I found this to be too cake-like. The taste was okay. The only change I made was reducing the cloves from 1/2 tsp to 1/4 tsp since I don't like cloves. The cake-y/muffin-y texture made it seem undercooked. Also, the icing was too sugary, and I couldn't get it to drizzle even after adding more milk. I'm almost never impressed w/ high-rated recipes, maybe b/c I have such high expectations for the recipe after reading the reviews. I don't think I'll be trying this recipe again.

text:
Regarding the quantity of pumpkin.  The first time I made these I accidentally used the whole can of pumpkin....not just one cup as called for in the recipe.  The second time I made them I (correctly) used one cup of pumpkin.  They were very good, just different than the first batch...not quite as moist, not quite as flavorful.  So the bottom line....the recipe is great as written.....but with a whole can of pumpkin they are amazing.  (FYI, the dough is sticky to work with..but it’s worth it.  Also, I put cinnamon in my icing/glaze)

Rating:

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:

userID:
12181061
Display Name:
JeaninLA
isPro:

2
favoritesCount:
93
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Be careful...there is pumpkin puree and next to it on the store shelf is pumpkin pie filling.  The first time I made this I used pumpkin puree as the recipe lists, and the second time I accidentally bought and used a can of pumpkin pie filling, which has sugar added to it already and is more runny.  The pumpkin puree version of this recipe is not as sweet, of course, and makes a more plump cookie, and tastes more like a pumpkin bread.  The second batch with the pumpkin pie filling was sweet like a cookie, since I still added the sugars, and it was more runny, so I added a little more flour and baking soda and powder.  They spread out more on the pan. I greased the cookie sheet well each time, but they still kind of stuck to it, and stuck together when cooled, so I had to put waxed paper in between them..  My husband liked both versions - the first as a more thick, plump pumpkin bread type cookie with icing, and the second as a sweeter cookie that did not need icing.  I did change the recipe to use 1 cup of white sugar and a half cup of brown sugar instead of all white sugar.

I really like this recipe. I followed the suggestions of several other reviewers in which I used about 14oz of pumpkin, added a bit more cinnamon, and substituted 1/2 cup of brown sugar. I usually find the recipes for pumpkin choc chip cookies bland so I chose to use a pumpkin spice recipe and it did not disappoint. I suggest using this recipe with the changes.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
These cookies are magnificent, and both kids and adults ask me to bake them again and again.  I use an entire can of the pumpkin (which is pretty close to what the recipe calls for, I think),  but my big trick is tripling the spices.  The cookies need more cinnamon, nutmeg, and especially clove *Boom*  to be autumn fabulous,  and tripling the spices works well; sometimes I shake in even more spice beyond tripling. 
Try making them in greased mini cupcake tins too.  They come out cute and very easy to serve – – just cool and then  drop them into mini cupcake papers. 
ALSO--I renamed them--haha! Because they rise and have a wonderful (and somewhat cake-like) consistency--which people love(!), they don't really seem like cookies, so I call them "Iced Pumpkin Tea Cakes" which seems to make people even more excited to try them.
Review:
Rating:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just joined this website specifically to leave a review on these cookies.   I really love these.  I use homemade pumpkin puree and make 2 double batches during the holidays every year and they are gobbled up.  I made these once last year with canned puree and that was the first and last time I will ever do that.  It's just not the same.  They are soft, tender, moist and very cake-like.  The first time I made them I thought I had messed them up because the dough is much softer than the typical cookie dough (at least for the limited cookie recipes I made), but that is how it's meant to be.   Spices can be kicked up or dialed down to your preference.  I don't care for cloves so I put 1/2 as much in as the recipe calls for, but if you like a lot of spice you can add more of everything or even add in ginger to really pump up the spice aspect of the cookies.   These also absolutely need the icing.  It's a recipe for an iced cookie so if you leave off one of the components, it's not how the cookie was meant to taste.  It really needs the extra sweetness of the icing and the glazed texture on top is really nice.

text:
I just made these tonight and WOW.  This is almost cake like it is so soft and moist, to me not the everyday traditional "cookie".  This was very easy and delicious.  Making this glaze I had cream cheese but I did not leave it out to soften, so I put 4oz.(half a brick) of it in a bowl and microwaved it for about 30 seconds to soften.  I then added the melted butter which added heat and stirred them together until mixed.  I then added the rest of the glaze ingredients.  I am not huge pumpkin lover, but these were REALLY good.  I am not a fan of hard cookies and these did not disappoint.  Before I knew it I had eaten 3 of them.  Like the other reviewer said these are DANGER DANGER!  I will be putting this one in the keeper folder of my recipe book.  Thanks.

Loved these cookies! I stayed pretty true to the recipe, and the only thing I did differently was using some brown sugar in place of white. A word of warning: the dough is EXTREMELY sticky and loose, almost like a muffin dough. This was one of those times when I was really happy to have bought a spring-loaded cookie scoop! The glaze was delicious too, but I put on half the cookies only, for the sake of variety. Thank you Gina!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just finished icing these... turned out delicious, like a cakey cookie version of pumpkin pie.  Followed the cookie dough recipe exactly.  Glaze - added a dash of cinnamon and ended up using about half the milk.
I'm neurotic, so here are some aesthetic suggestions:
These are not a drop cookie.  The dough is wet/sticky but it sets exactly as you put it on the cookie sheet.  So my first batch turned out 'rustic' looking (like mini-scones) because I thought they'd smooth out in baking.  My work around was to let the dough sit on the cookie sheet and the edge dry a bit, then you can form it/smooth it... turned out much nicer looking.  Also these stay very moist so be careful if you stack them.. they tend to stick together.

country:
None
text:
Greatest cookie recipe ever! Soft, chewy & not to sweetI made it as written the first time; they were fantastic. The second time I tried it, I made a few modifications, as per another reviewer - I added the full (15oz) can of pumpkin, half white/half brown sugar, and 1tbsp of pumpkin pie spice. Oh my, even better! I've even made them gluten-free, subbing 2cups of GF flour mix for the AP flour. The GF ones took longer to cook (about 20 min), but turned out just as tasty. You couldn't even tell they were GF! I will be making these year round!  (Oh, I didn't ice them.)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are too much extra work if you want to use real pumpkin puree. I had to add around 1/4 c flour, soak my hands in cold water and grease them 2-3 times per sheet, and cook them for an extra 5-8 minutes to get anything resembling what's pictured and described by other reviewers. If you use real puree and don't add flour, you'll get incredibly sticky, flat, somewhat dense discs. I couldn't even scrape them off the parchment paper I used when baking. Although the taste was alright (everyone who tried them said they were tasty), the next time I want to make pumpkin cookies, I'll look elsewhere.

These are amazing. Not overly pumpkin-y in flavour. Just a hint. My husband loved them and he doesn't like anything pumpkin. I used a cream cheese icing on top instead of the one listed. I just drizzled it on top instead of fully coating. The perfect amount of sweetness. Other reviewers said that 10 minutes was all the bake needed and I agree. I made 3 batches at 10 minutes each and they came out perfect. Light and fluffy. I used fresh pumpkin puree instead of canned. I donated them to our local police station. Big hit!

These cookies were a HUGE hit.  Even the seven year old loved them!  They were very moist and flavorful.  This cookie took on a cake consistency, which was a pleasant surprise.  I don't even like pumpkin, and I was the one having one at each meal.  I  will be making them again.  Though you might want to refrigerate them to keep the frosting hard.  Here in GA the humidity prevents it from solidifying if you leave them contained on the counter. I love this website; I can't say I've ever made a bad recipe from it.

text:
After making adjustments for 6200 altitude - namely 2 TBSP more flour, 1/4 less sugar, reducing the soda and baking soda both to 3/4 tsp and raising the baking temp to 365 degrees - I found the dough very stiff and the first batch did not spread so we're 50 cent size.  I mixed another egg in the remaing dough and the cookies spread better and tasted fine!

Display Name:
Patches

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/707415.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
What a welcome change from the usual "really sweet" cookie.  I had enough leftover pumpkin (from the Pumpkin Cake III on this site) to make this recipe.  After reading the reviews, I made a few minor changes ... I know, I know,  why rate it then ... well, if you're interested, read on.  I didn't have enough softened butter so I added about 1/8 cup of applesauce to make up the cup required.  I used 3/4 c white and 3/4 c brown sugar and added 1 c of dried cranberries.  A small cookie scoop equaled 70 cookies, baked on parchment paper for 12 minutes.  I flattened some with the back of a wet spoon and left some of them "round".  The round ones could have used another minute in the oven, I think.  I had leftover cream cheese glaze which I drizzled on some of the cookies. Personally, I loved the subtle taste of the cookie better without the cream cheese.  Maybe the glaze in this recipe would complement the cookie better.  Thanks, Gina, for a lovely basic recipe.

As a concha, this recipes rocks. The texture, sweetness, everything about it reminds me of Mexican sweet bread. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2725039.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My dad, loves bulk buying. One thing he always gets is a #10 sized can of Yams. Oy! So when that can makes it to the kitchen I make 3 sweet potato pies, 1 sweet potato pound cake, and a double batch of these cookies. These are delish and I usually forgo the icing. For a single batch: I also include 1/2 tsp of ginger and 1/4 tsp of Allspice and 1/2 tsp of Almond extract. I get a bit of a stickier dough when I add about 1/2 cup extra yams, but the amount is fine as is and it really doesn't effect the end product. (I just need to polish off that ginormous can!)The scent is intoxicating! Like others, I only bake on parchment paper and flatten these with the bottom of a glass dipped in granulated sugar. Enjoy, baker buddies!

This recipe creates a great cookie!  Soft, fluffy, subtle flavoring..  I'm not sure I added all the flour, because I lost count (doubled the recipe), but the cookies baked up nice and fluffy, and the icing really made them pop.

I made these for a company Thanksgiving luncheon, and people having been raving, going so far as to call them "pumpkin clouds".  I will repeat a warning not to put them in an airtight container though, they did get a little soggy, but that didn't stop the raves.

I'll definitely be making these again.

text:
Just made these tonight. They are yummy! Kids and husband did not even wait till I iced them! I made one modification based on other reviews: I used 1 cup of white sugar plus 1/2 cup of brown sugar. Other than that I followed the recipe as written. As another reviewer mentioned these cookies do not spread while baking. They come out of the oven exactly as they went in. My first batch was kind of "spiky" since I used an ice cream scoop to drop them on the pan. The next batch I smoothed the tops with a wet finger and they came out beautifully. I used the icing in the recipe (adding a little cinnamon). Some I fully iced the tops and some my daughter drizzled icing on. My family preferred the ones with just a little icing (or none at all!) I will be making another batch to take to our family Thanksgiving dinner!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/154.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These came out pretty good. I followed the suggestions of some other reviewers and used 1 cup white sugar & 1/2 cup brown sugar, one 15 oz. can of pumpkin, and put cinnamon in the glaze. I found that these did not spread very much in the oven while they baked. Pay attention when these are in the oven; my first tray was done in 11 minutes, but the second one needed another 4 minutes, and then when the heat was raised the rest were done in a little under 12 minutes. 


The cookie itself tastes (to me) a lot like pumpkin pie, because of the pumpkin and spices used. It definitely needed the glaze; the pumpkin and spices overpowered the sugar. 



Everything has room for improvement, so I'm giving it four stars, but these are definitely satisfactory. 


Something worth mentioning, however, is that when the cookies are fresh out of the oven, they have a tendency to stick together. Let them completely cool before glazing or storing them.

text:
These were excellent!  The only modification was that I added additional pumpkin pie spice to the already listed spices, (which could actually be achieved by using slightly more of the spices called  for here). Also, I ALWAYS double the vanilla in every recipe I bake.  The results were a moist, and perfectly spiced cake-like cookie. If you like your desserts a little less sweet, than omit the icing, but with the addition of the icing it was the perfect finish to my thanksgiving lunch with the girls!  Everyone was wowed by them, even those who said they typically don't eat anything "pumpkin". The kids were also big fans too! With the icing of course!

Fantastic! Baked them for almost twenty minutes to get the crispy on the outside and soft on the inside texture. So good.

userID:
3165283
Display Name:
Bhamster
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
They  DO spread. I put 15 cookies on one sheet, but they puffed and spread quite a bit so that they were all squished together. I did better with 8 cookies on a sheet. 

Because it's more of a batter than a dough, I had trouble flattening them without making a mess. What I finally did was refrigerate the batter then scoop each cookie directly into a custard cup filled with turbinado sugar. Then I flattened with the bottom of an orange juice glass. Since I don't like bothering with icing (even if it is good), I prefer adding turbinado sugar to give added sweetness and a nice crunch.

Cookies are good, but I had to take away stars just because of the difficulty of having to come up with a system for flattening without a sticky mess.

Oh yes: and 12 minutes was sufficient with a little time to cool on the cookie sheets first. Subbed 1/2 cup of the sugar for brown.

country:
None
text:
We LOVE and I mean LOVE this cookie in our house!  I just found this recipe but I think it's going to be one that I will make year round.  I like that it doesn't use as much butter as other cookie reipces and has the added pumpkin for nutrition.  Having said that I did omit the cloves because I can't stand them and increased the cinnamon to three teaspoons.  Cinnamon is also really healthy for you.   We also like them plain rather than frosted but I think a cream cheese type frosting would be much better than the one used that is posted to this recipe.  Others said storage is an issue for these.  If put into a zip bag they get moist and stick to each other and the frosting gets soft and icky.  I also put colored sugar/sprinkles on the colored frosting and had an ugly mess.  The last time I made them I just wrapped them in a dish towel that I use only for covering bread or cinnamon rolls while raising and they were just perfect!  So in the future when they are done cooling I'll just put them into a bowl and wrap them with the dish towel .   They are a more of a cake like cookie but really YUMMY!  Love this one!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-10-24T20:26:14.433
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
10147697
Display Name:
theteenagebaker16
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I"m making these as I type, and honestly they're heavenly from the moment you take them out of the oven. Their aroma filled with the kitchen with a simple kind of bliss, and that was only the beginning of the magic of these cookies. Don't be dismayed by their cake like texture when putting them on the cookie sheet. You have to use a spoon, and just make sure every cookie has a generous portion to avoid burning. They were fairly simple to make, and I used pumpkin pie spice rather than doing the cinnamon, nutmeg, etc. separately. After being baked, they were very light. My family loves the texture, and you don't have to worry about these being too rich. The pumpkin taste wasn't super strong, but it was certainly noticeable and apparent. If this is negative, I'm sure a bit more pumpkin puree could easily fix this. Now on to the glaze. It was extremely simple to create, and just add the milk in slowly. You won't need as much as you think, and it's very light as well. The taste can be compared to that of gingerbread house frosting. You don't need much on the cookie, they're good enough by themselves. They don't spread much, in that way they're more similar to cake. Overall, this is one of my favorite recipes and I will certainly be using is again as well as recommending it to others. A great fall recipe, and I hope everyone enjoyed it as much as me!
Review:

5

text:
These cookies are great as is, but... I tweak them a bit for my tastes. I use  brown sugar instead of white (I actually just used organic coconut palm sugar) and 2 tsp of pumpkin pie spice instead of individual spices. For the frosting I throw in about 1/8 c of white chocolate chips in with the melting butter then add 1/2 & 1/2 instead of milk. Whisk quickly until smooth then off the heat add vanilla, then add to powdered sugar. I sometimes will add a pinch of pumpkin pie spice to the frosting as well. Love these cookies!

text:
These were very delicious when I allowed to cook for only 12 minutes, added more vanilla, a dash of ginger, 1 cup of white sugar and 3/4 cup of brown sugar, and loads more cinnamon(we love cinnamon)oh and I added cinnamon to the icing.  I made drops of teaspoon size and tried to flatten. They came out perfectly like a muffin top! I drizzled the icing up and down and then side to side instead of just pouring it on. It was a great recipe and I will make it again, only I will add chopped pecans next time. Thanks

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is truly delicious! 

A few pointers: 

I  added a tsp of all-spice to my batter. 

for the Glaze: be careful not to add to much confectioners sugar to the glaze. I found its best to have a consistency somewhere between syrup and molasses; syrup-texture is a bit to thin and will run off the cookie, while molasses-texture will not spread and will rip up the cookie if you try. 

Also, I heated the canned pumpkin in a pan with the spices and vanilla extract before adding it to the mixing bowl. This made the pumpkin taste fresher, not like it came from a can, and ensured the spices where infused into the pumpkin. Trust me this makes a HUGE difference.

Everyone that has tried these cookies has a mouth-gasm. Enjoy!

So, I tried this recipe again, with a little experiment: After making the dough (Using half brown sugar, half white, and using the -whole- can of pumpkin) I split the dough evenly between two bowls and added 3/4 cup chopped pecans top one bowl, and 3/4 cup chocolate chips to the other bowl. Baked both for about 14 minutes and they turned out great! This is such a versatile recipe :)

edit: OOPS!! I DIDN'T FOLLOW THE RECIPE!!! I just realized as I was recording my notes that the recipe calls for 1 CUP canned pumpkin . . . I used 1 can (15 oz = ~1.75 cup) of pumpkin.  It turned out perfect.  Maybe one day I will try with just 1 cup . .   ORIGINAL REVIEW: Delicious, cakey.  I added a tbs of applesauce after I tasted the batter.  I doubt it made any difference, but I had felt the batter was a slightly too floury and I didn't want to add more butter.  Cooked for 15 min for my gigantic (2" dia) cookies and 12 min for the small (1.5") ones.  It was hard to tell if the cookies were done by looking at it, but it was the perfect time.

text:
These cookies are abslolutely delicious! My entire family loves them, including my son who doesn't like pumpking.  They were a big hit in my office.  They go great with coffee.  You can also add chopped walnuts or chocalate chips.  You can substitute the confectioners sugar for just powder sugar and you get a thicker frosting. 
If you over cook, don't worry... cover over night and they become softer and moist.
Enjoy!

text:
I'm gluten-free so I substituted King Arthur Gluten Free Multi-purpose flour and added 3/4 tsp xantham gum. Added 1 1/3 cup of pumpkin puree since I had extra from a pumpkin pie I was making. Baked on parchment paper for 12 minutes as others suggested. When I tried my first one I just about melted - I was like whoaaa these are SO GOOD! Great texture and taste. I didn't do the icing because it was pretty sweet and I thought it might overpower the blend of spices (which were flavorful and perfect). Thanks for a wonderful recipe! This one's going to be a regular on my list. I got 54 cookies using a tablespoon of batter for each one.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
LOVE this recipe! I have never rated a recipe before, but I must say this is spot on. I didn't have any cloves on hand so I just left them out, and I didn't quite have a full cup of regular butter so I threw in a tbsp on margarine and they still came out great! I like my cookies a little bigger and was able to make 20 good sized cookies from this recipe. Don't let the dough scare you, it may seem a bit runny because of the pumpkin, but I popped mine in the fridge for 1/2 and hour and they turn out beautifully! Also, if you don't have confectioner sugar on hand you can make a fabulous glaze with 1/2 cup regular sugar and 1/3 water brought to a boil until thickened :)  Thanks Gina!!

text:
Best cookie recipe ever!
I make this at least 5 times a year, and everyone always asks for two things: more cookies and the recipe.
I find that I have a lot of frosting left over, so I just double the cookie batter and keep the frosting amount the same. The frosting does harden a bit between batches in the oven, but as soon as the frosting touches the warm cookies, it spreads just fine.

text:
I agree with another reviewer that these don't have to be flattened. I used the glaze in the recipe and thought it was very good as written. I also added a half of pecan to the top of the cookie before baking and felt it needed that for some substance. Another reviewer had added a walnut; however, I had the pecans and like pecan with pumpkin. That same reviewer suggested adding some chopped nuts to the batter and I also think I will do that next time to add substance to the cookie. It is kind of bland without any nuts in it. Otherwise this is a very nice "Thanksgiving holiday" addition to my desserts for a cookie. I only baked it the 15 minutes and that was plenty. They will harden a bit as they cool. The house smells wonderful while they are cooking!

text:
I made this for a friends birthday party. After making a couple of test cookies (delicious!) I decided that the texture was spongy and soft enough to pour the batter into a cake tin to make a cookie cake, which I then drizzled the glaze over. I used about 1 1/2 cups pumpkin purée, about 1/3 cup extra white sugar and didn't go easy on the cinnamon and it was one of the best things I (and the party goers) had ever tasted. Hold onto this one, guys! It's a gem!

text:
If you're looking for a soft, cake-like cookie these are for you! These cookies are wonderful!  I wanted to rate it a 5 star recipe, but there are just a couple little things that I would change.  I took the advice and substituted 1/2 c. brown sugar for white.  Also, the spices are a little lacking.  Next time I plan to add a 1/2 tsp. more cinnamon and add the recommended 1/2 tsp. ground ginger.  I did not add the cinnamon or spice to the glaze.  I will DEFINITELY be making these every year around Fall and the Holidays.  They are just delicious and very comforting.  Also, I took some other advice and baked for 12 minutes.  PERFECT! :)

text:
These cookies were absolutely delicious and so easy to make! My 11yo son and I followed the recipe exactly and they came out perfectly! We used my favorite cream cheese frosting on top-
1 stick butter softened
1 8oz package cream cheese softened
1 tsp vanilla
3 cups powdered sugar
Cream butter and cream cheese then add vanilla. Add powdered sugar by the cup. This makes enough for a 9 X 13" sheet cake.

This was delicious.  I didn't use the glaze.  Instead I bought a can of cream cheese frosting and put it in the microwave for 30 seconds to soften it and put it on top of the cookies.  It will harden to the touch.  I left the cookies rounded (didn't flatten at all) and baked 2 cookie sheets at a time for 20 minutes.

The second time I made this recipe, I reduced the amount of pumpkin to 2/3 cup. You could still taste the pumpkin, but the texture was much more like a cookie. Try adding cinnamon to the glaze to give the cookie an extra kick. I also went ahead and added rainbow sprinkles (tacky but so delicious!). When I brought these to my class, all my friends were asking for the recipe. These cookies are my new "thing."

text:
Very good cookie.  Both my husband and inlaws really liked the flavor and texture.  I made a few modifications: 3/4 c whole wheat flour, 1/4 c ground oats, and remaining amount of flour was all purpose.  1 mashed sweet potato for pumpkin and equal amounts of brown sugar and white sugar.  These are quick, easy, and delicious.  These are so easy to make that a child could make them with some supervision.  Baking is a great confidence booster to children!

Display Name:
kjb

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cookie is so wonderful that you will want to share!  (That is, if there are any left!)  They are a soft cookie that can be enjoyed anytime of year, but are perfect during the autumn season.  The glaze adds a pretty touch that sets it off. Be sure to watch your baking time as to not over bake.  Only you can know your oven on how hot  it  bakes, so adjust baking time accordingly.  I like to add 1/4 tsp of ginger to the recipe to enhance the flavor.  Although I lprefer this glaze, you can use your desired amount of white canned frosting with 1/4 tsp to 1/2 tsp of cinnamon added to it.  Put the white frosting in microwave for a few seconds to make it a drizzling consistency and then drizzle with fork over cookies.  These cookies even tasted better the next day, that is if they last that long!

These were a hit with my friends, who said "they taste like fall."  Next time, I will put walnuts and raisins in half the batch for increased texture, which is my personal preference. For the glaze, I used maple flavoring, 2 TBSP Apple Cider, 1 TBSP milk, 2 cups sifted powdered sugar, 1/4 tsp cinnamon, and 1 TBSP melted butter. The glaze turned out very well and complimented the cookie flavors.

text:
These cookies are AMAZING!  I didn't feel as guilty eating "just one more" because of the pumpkin in them. ;)  I made the following changes to the recipe:    3/4 cp brown sugar + 3/4 cp white sugar (instead of 1 1/2 cp white sugar)  3 tsp. pumpkin pie spice (instead of the cinnamon, ginger, and cloves)    I also added some chocolate chips but these cookies are yummy enough that they are not needed.  I did not make icing for these cookies (they were gone before I could!) so I cannot comment on the icing.

So I actually found this recipe on another website, and they were called Pumpkin Blossoms. You know, like the Peanut Butter Blossoms!! Buy the Pumpkin spice hershey kisses and put them on after about 5 minutes of cooling. I also unwrapped all my kisses and put them in the freezer while the cookies were baking, so they wouldn't melt right away after being placed on the cookie. These were amazing, I also did the icing.. DELICIOUS! :) Happy Fall.

text:
These are fantastic! Made two batches in one week!!  My boyfriend loves them!  The first time through I made it exactly as directed although I put the flour mixture into the wet mixture in two stages.  The second time I made it I added more cinnamon to my tastes and a little more of each spice.  Also on the second round I used cream cheese icing instead, just swapped the butter for the cheese.  They were fantastic.  Thank you so much for the wonderful recipe!  It's a keeper!  If you thin the icing enough you can dunk the tops of the cookies in the icing and pull them out so you don't have to drizzle, or if you just like more sweetness go for it!!

We love these cookies!!! If you like pumpkin they are an absolute must!!!  I have made them over a dozen times and they turn out great everytime. I put cream cheese in the frosting, it was very tasty but the frosting stayed gooey(bad for stacking,but oh my goodness!!!!)... I crushed pecans and put them on top of the cookies when the frosting still wet.... I put a 1/2 cup of pecans in the cookies... All of these modifications were successful and very yummy!!
