userID:
4346936
Display Name:
Our family
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
19
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
When my wife makes these, I could sit down and eat the entire batch before too long.  I personally would go with the glaze. Cream cheese is too concentrated of a flavor and texture.  These cookies have to be balanced by the right topping.  Eating them plain reveals them to be a pretty straight forward flavor.  The glaze is indeed delicate and it's firmness, once set, balances the texture of the "cake" cookie.  I'd eat it with cream cheese if I had to, but that glaze is mind tingling.  I'm also not in favor of "icing" the cookie with the glaze, make it uneven.  The mouth wants to search for the glaze.  Lord, there's such a ying and yang to these.  And for heaven's sake don't spoil it with chocolate chips.  You're liable to throw the whole thing out of balance.  Amazing... these cookies are amazing.

country:
None
text:
These were outstanding...the second time I made them and adjusted them for ALTITUDE  To adjust for altitude and maintain the cakey (not cookie) like consistency of the cookie, I added an extra yolk, reduced the baking soda and flour each by 1/8 tsp, increased all the spices by ~1/2 tsp, doubled the vanilla, and reduced the sugar by 2 tbs (I used 1c white sugar and 1/2c brown, of which i took out the 2 tbs).   Make sure cookies cool completely before icing. I prefer dipping the tops as opposed to dropping on the icing with a fork, it looks much better

dateLastModified:

userID:
3023586
Display Name:
kristinafit
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe twice; it is a good recipe, but the cookies are soft and have a cake like texture. If you want a harder texture, then you wont like this recipe. I tried it with fresh pumpkin, because I had a little left over from something else I made (I wouldn't have made them otherwise) but I don't think that would have made a difference. I put half with chocolate chips so my friend who is not a pumpkin person would eat it, but it tasted better without. My father who is very traditional, did like them, but preferred the pie and cakes I made with pumpkin. I did not use the frosting because I think they are sweet enough without them, especially if you put chips. You must remember to grease the pan. I know that sounds obvious, but the first time I made it, I tried the first batch without greasing the pan, not noticing the recipe said to grease it. I had to throw the whole first batch out. I am used to making toll house cookie recipes which contain a little more fat, so you don't need to grease the pan. This recipe only calls for a half a stick of butter and really does not have a lot of fat, content, so the cookies really stick if you don't grease it. All in all, it is a great recipe, as long as you follow the instructions carefully.

I made these last night and they were delicious! For the spices, I took the advice of another reviewer and subbed 1 1/2 tsp. cinnamon and 1 1/2 tsp. pumpkin pie spice for the other spices. I only baked them at 12 minutes and then, as the oven got hotter, reduced them to 10. Also, the glaze didn't need any additional milk...you could probably get by with a little less than 3 tbsp.

text:
I love this recipe - yummy cakey pumpkin cookies!  5 stars with one caveat - per other reviews - you need to add more spices than what is called for in the recipe. I think that one user substituted pumpkin spice - i added more spices and added some spice to the glaze as well. The first time I made this i used the butter called for in the glaze and it never set well enough for me. The second time I omitted the butter and it came out perfectly.  This recipe has earned its place in my holiday cookie (or anytime cookie) collection

text:
These cookies are a little soft inside (cake-like) and full of flavor.  The icing is a simple; I just added a pinch of cinnamon and immediately sprinkled chopped pecans on top of the cookies.   When I bake or if I the time I try to measure everything out the night before, so I can be sure I have everything I need.  This extra step saves time and ensures unnecessary mistakes.    Because I use a small ice cream scooper, the recipe made enough for me to give a dozen to my sister, my mom and a few to my neighbor.  The next day they called and said “the Pumpkin pie cookies” were delicious.  Now, they want to order some for their family and friends for the Holidays.  I’m adding this to my Holiday cookie file.  Thanks for this great recipe!

I will try this one again, using it step by step. I doubled the recipe, used 1/2 brown & white sugars, and added about 1/4 cup more pumpkin, because that was the rest of it. (Silly to see it go to waste).  I DIDN'T have problems with the cookies flattening out, because of the add'l pumpkin.  ALSO, Pampered Chef Stoneware and a #50 Cookie Scoop gave me just the right mount of cookies. I baked them for the full 20 minutes. I also added mini chocolate chips to half the dough.  As I stated earlier, I'll try these again and see if I get a fluffier texture, like I was expecting. I had these types of cookies before, but maybe it was my modifications that made them different from what I was looking for.

text:
This type of cookie (more cake-like) is not usually my 5-star favorite; however, this recipe is so versatile that I did give it 5-stars.  I did substitute 1/2 cup brown sugar for white and did the same for flour substituting 1 cup of wheat flour in.    I made 3 different icings: the recipes (powdered sugar icing), cream cheese icing, and Pumpkin Cookie V brown sugar/powdered sugar icing which I liked best. My DH liked the cream cheese the best. I split the brown sugar icing in half and mixed toasted pecans in. On the cream cheese and regular icing, I alternated sprinkling iced cookies with cinnamon or toasted pecan pieces. It looked like I had a whole tray of different kinds of cookies out of the same batch. Guaranteed to please everyone! I did add pecans to my batter to the last half of my batter as well and then finally made some with mini chocolate chips (which surprisingly, I didn't really care for even though).   Thanks for the good fall pumpkin recipe. Now I have 3 pumpkin favorites: pumpkin pie, pumpkin dessert, and these cookies.

This recipe made me fall in love with baking! Every fall I make these and they are a hit! This season already I've made 10 dozen of them to pass out to friends and family. One hint: when placing the dough on cookie sheets use two spoons and then after all the dough is placed go back and shape the cookies with your hands.  I found this way keeps my hands clean and gives the cookies a more rounded shape.

text:
I don't really know if they are the best as it was my first attempt of Pumpkin Cookies... but they are so tasty and moist that I wouldn't change the recipe for an other one. Even my husband who really don't like pumpkin ate all his part and try to eat mine... I usually froze my pumpkin raw. I peel it and cut the flesh in cube. As we don't have canned pumpkin puree in France, I used my frozen cubes. I let them in the fridge all the night and then I microwaved them 9 min. I separated the flesh from the water (press the pumpkin well to extract all the water) and pureed the flesh in my blender. And it worked perfectly.

userID:
3816286
Display Name:
JPC222
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

4
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/314614.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I absolutely LOVED these! The pumpkin/spice flavor is perfect but not too sweet, the texture is soft like a cake, not a cookie really, but it works well for this recipe. I didn’t have cloves, but used allspice instead, and I slightly mounded the measurements of cinnamon, nutmeg, and allspice to add more spice flavor =) I also did 1 ¼ cups white, and ¼ cup brown sugar to keep the cookie tender (not sure if this is needed since the cookie came out so tender anyway). I did a little more than a full cup of pumpkin puree by adding in a few more spoonfuls of it, to keep it moist and to add more pumpkin flavor. Also, since I heard these should be a little sweeter, I mixed in some splenda as well. The batter was a very sticky, dropped by bigger spoonfuls and smoothed with my finger.  Baked for 12 minutes, these came out looking beautiful, round, and puffy, with some cracks on the top. Very moist and delicious. I added cinnamon to the icing and drizzled a good amount on with a fork. PERFECT. Will make again and again!

Other people have called these cookies "muffin tops". I have to agree. I thought the flavor was good but very muffin/cake like. These are delicious!  I have to 'vegan-ize' these cookies since I have a daughter allergic to eggs and dairy.  For each egg, I use 1T flax meal mixed with 3T water, and I use canola oil instead of butter.  They come out sooooo good!  I'm sure they would be just as yummy as is, with the eggs and butter.  These are so soft and the spices make them taste great!  You have to try them!

text:
A great fall treat! I used a bit (1/4 c.) more pumpkin and swapped 1/2 c. of the white sugar with brown sugar, as someone recommended. The icing measurements made way too much icing - if you are only going to drizzle it, you could make half the amount and it would be fine. It's also definitely worth adding some cinnamon to the icing! yum!

text:
I made these cookies without the frosting.  I found it to be a really good pumpkin cookie recipe.  I added a bit more pumpkin than called for and I got cookies that were super moist - almost like pumpkin bread cookies.  Note: The more spice you add to these, the better they taste.  I used 1 tsp pumpkin pie spice and 2 tsp cinnamon.
I used brown sugar instead of white and  I only used 1 cup.

Divine! The spices reminds me of the holidays and my whole house smelled good when I made them. Very cake like and the other reviewers were right about how moist the cookie is. I left the out all day and they stayed perfectly fresh. The only modification to the recipe that I made was the icing application. I poured the icing in to a zip-lock bag and cut a tiny corner off the bottom then squeezed the icing on to the cookie.

AMAZING COOKIES! My coworkers scarfed them down today.  Here is the recipe I used for frosting (from another recipe on the site):
CINNAMON FROSTING: 
1/2 cup butter, softened 
2 1/2 cups confectioners' sugar 
2 tablespoons milk 
1 teaspoon ground cinnamon 
1 teaspoon vanilla extract

text:
Amazing! So moist and cakey. I made these a day ahead for a Halloween party and had to hide some from my boyfriend. 
I did follow the advice of other reviewers and increased the pumpkin to 15oz of homemade puree and used 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1 cup Splenda for Baking.
Because the dough was so sticky, I floured my hands and a board with confectioner's sugar and patted them down to about 3" rounds and skipped the icing.
I also used all freshly ground spices which gave them an awesome punch that I'm not sure they would have had otherwise.
Will certainly make again... soon!

Fabulous recipe!  The icing came out too thick for me to drizzle, so I added in a bit more vanilla & milk.  This made it more of a drizzle consistency & not as overpoweringly sweet.  I've never been good at drizzling with a fork, so after mixing the icing, I poured it into a 2-cup Pyrex measuring cup so I could use the spout to drizzle.  I can't wait to take these to work!

country:

text:
TIP: To easily flatten out cookies, dab your finger in some water and smooth around the dough.  This will prevent the "peaks" some are experiencing.  Replaced half of the white sugar with light brown sugar; used "I Can't Believe it's Not Butter."  The spice flavors are wonderful!  Also, to evenly coat with the icing, just turn the cookie upside down once cooled, and dip it in.  Much easier than frosting with a knife!  I baked for 13-14 min. at the suggested temp.  Enjoyed..and will make again!

None
text:
These cookies are delicious!! I tweaked the recipe a bit though. I didn't have any ground cloves, so I used about 1/4 tsp. of ground ginger instead (that is what I had on hand). Also, instead of 1 1/2 cup white sugar, I used 1 cup of white, and 1/2 cup of dark brown sugar.

Once the cookies cooled completely, I placed the glaze in a ziplock bag and cut a small hole in the corner to drizzle. I stuck them in the fridge for a bit so the glaze would harden. They look as good as they taste! I will definitely make these again!!!

text:
These are AWESOME! I did tweak it a little because I can never leave a recipe as is :P The first changes were actually an accident! Instead of putting only 1/2 tsp of the cloves & nutmeg I put in a full tsp. I guess to kinda "even it out" and/or just add more yumminess to it I added a tsp of pumpkin pie spice as well. With the pumpkin puree I did about 1 1/4 cup as well. For the icing I added 1T of cinnamon & instead of using a fork to drizzle it on the cookies I put the icing in a plastic ziplock baggie and cut off one corner just to make a small hole for drizzling... worked like a charm! Using the medium cookie dough scoop I got 34 delicious cookies! I split the batch with hubby to take to work and were all gone within an hour! This recipe is definatly a keeper!

text:
These were sooo good! I made directly as instruced with just a couple of minor alterations. The icing calls for 3T of milk which made a really thick consistency. I used 5T and it was still thick and did not "drizzle" well. I ended up adding a dash of cinnamon to the icing and iced the cookies instead of drizzling. They were soft and very good! They were gone in a day. This recipe is a keeper!

Technically this is 4 1/2 stars.  These are delicious little pillows of pumpkin!  Very good.  I had a party and everyone raved at how delicious they were.  They were cakey, but light.  My only issue was that the icing on them got mushy and runny after a day.  They really had to be kept in the fridge.  By 2 days, they were starting to look unattractive because of the icing and just getting smooshed in general.  Very delicious and lovely the day of though.

text:
i have made these cookies too many times to count, it's now a regular request from my family and friends. the recipe is great but i make a few adjustments. i use all whole wheat flour, substitute the butter for applesauce, use 4 tsp of cinnamon, 2 tsp of nutmeg, 2 tsp of cloves, and add 1 or 2 tsp of ginger. i also add 1 c of chocolate chips, and do not glaze the cookies. my cookies come out with a pumpkin-pie like taste, and a dense yet fluffy, cake-like consistency.

this cookie was PERFECT! it was soft and big and cake-like. the only down side was that i made them on a humid day and the dough was a little sticky. i will absoultely make them again, regardless of the humidity issue. the icing was great too. i halved the icing recipe and covered half of the cookies with the icing and i covered the other half of the batch with a cream cheese frosting. the cream cheese ones had a better apperance but both the icing and the frosting were great!

a definite KEEPER! :)

One day my daughter decided that she wanted to butcher our pumpkin that we wanted to use to make a jack-o-lantern. So we cooked and pured the pumpkin and put it in the freezer.We were trying to find some great pumpkin recipes, that werent pumplin pie (I hate pumpkin pie), we came across this one. We acually made our own cream cheese icing and it was a hit at our family scrabble night (Yes! Scrabble night...). My daughter even took them to school for snack and she is A a VERY picky eater. You should be very proud of this recipe. it is the most requested dessert at our family gatherings. And its actually a little healthy!

text:
These cookies are really tasty.  I used a cookie scoop to drop the cookies directly onto the cookie sheet.  No need to flatten the cookies.  They will come out perfectly.  For the icing, I used a wire whisk.  I kept the cookies on a baking rack (with a cookie sheet underneath).  I just dipped the whisk into the icing and then drizzled over the cookies.  These cookies are soft and delicious.

userID:
945554
Display Name:
Cornpop
isPro:

2

44

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/62518.jpg
city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yumm! After a taste test I decided not to add the icing.  Maybe next time.  I did add mini chocolate chips to the batter.

For High Altitude I adjusted the baking powder to be 3/4 tsp, add 1/4 of flour, and scaled back on the sugar (if you typically bake in high altitudes this shouldn't be a surprise). I did use splenda for baking too.  This cookie batter is a tad sticky.  

If you place the dough covered in the fridge for say 7-10 minutes it'll form nicely as you place your mounds on the cookie sheet.

Perhaps sans the choc chips and without icing these may be a little one dimesional for the palate.  Play around with this one!  My house smells like the hoidays :)
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2007-10-22T19:04:53.523
helpfulCount:

text:
This cookie is awesome!!!! I followed the recipe exactly. I was nervous to make this cookie because some of the reviews that the batter is very sticky but I had no trouble at all since I used a cookie scooper, thank goodness. It looked exactly like the picture. Also, the frosting is very very sweet so I suggest using as much or as little as your tastebuds desire. The fork technique mentioned in the recipe to cover the cookie with frosting doesn't work very well. I placed the frosting inside a zip lock bag and cut a small hold, then drizzled it over the cookies. Worked like a breeze.

I had a hard time deciding what to rate this cookie. They are very good & I love all things pumkin, but the texture could improve. The recipe written for the glaze needs to be altered also. These will be added into the holiday cookie collection, and probably will be made throughout the year as well.

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2006-10-22T15:57:55.44
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1411580
Display Name:
BBLUELINE
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

42

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/20384.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum. These cookies are so good. I make them every year for our Christmas bake sale.  They are more like mini-cakes rather than a chewy cookie though. But that's half the reason why I like them! So if you are expecting chewy, stick with a chocolate chip cookie recipe. The only changes I made are to use half brown, half white sugar and only a total of 1 cup. I also add 1/4 cup of wheat germ. I only put a sprinkle of the nutmeg and use a whole small can of pumpkin instead of 1 cup. I also throw in a cup of milk chocolate chips. Then for the icing I use only 1 cup of icing sugar, the 1 tbsp butter and 1 tsp vanilla and then add milk until it thins. I recommend refrigerating these in an airtight container as they get really moist as they sit and sometimes the icing stays drippy instead of hardening slightly.
Great recipe for fall and smells SO good while baking!

text:
Amazing! I decided to try this recipe to give out to my family and friends for christmas, and I'm so glad I did! I followed the recipe exactly except for the cloves, which I just didnt have. After the first batch came out a little spikey, I sprayed some pam on my hands and rolled them into balls, then flattened with a glass and they came out picture perfect.  They are delicious plain, or if you want it a bit sweeter the icing is good as well. Even a cream cheese frosting would compliment thses nicely.  Regardless, you have to try these!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are light, fluffy cookies that are more like little spiced cakes. The texture, flavor, and moistness of the finished product were perfect! 

I didn't have ground cloves, so I threw in some allspice and ground cardamom instead. I also added more of the spices in general because you can never have too much cinnamon. And I always double the amount of vanilla in any recipe. 

As for the glaze, it also worked out perfectly! I was apprehensive because my glazes usually don't dry, leaving sticky, unstackable cookies. I was also making it with water because I didn't have milk. To my delight, this glaze dried almost immediately to the ideal hardness. I think I will be using it with other recipes whenever a basic sugar glaze is needed.
Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

userID:

Display Name:
JZPHSMOM

4

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I give this recipe 3.5 stars if you make it as is. did one batch as is, then tried something new. I added allspice(1T), 2T of orange juice(freshly squeezed from an orange) and 2t grated orange zest(from inside of peel, and some crushed pecans to the icing. I added allspice(1/2t)and 1C orange flavored craisins to the batter. I simmered the icing over low heat stirring constantly to make the icing more like a glaze. OH MY STARS!!!! TRY THIS!  The glaze seeps in a tiny bit to the cookie and it makes it like a mini cake. the craisins add a ton of moisture and added flavor and it is a party in the mouth. TRUST ME on this. Happy baking! Store in airtight container. they can dry out in a hurry.

text:
Fantastic cookies!  I wasn't sure I was going to like these, as I'm not generally a fan of cakey cookies.  However, they taste delicious, like little muffins. The house smells wonderful while baking these.  Instead of using 1/2 cup butter, I used 1/4 cup margarine + 1/4 cup applesauce.  I added about 1/2 teaspoon additional cinnamon.  I eyeballed the nutmeg, as I had to grate mine.  Instead of using 1 1/2 cups white sugar, I used 1 cup regular sugar + 1/2 cup brown sugar.  I also subbed egg replacer for the 1 egg.  Even with my adjustments, this turned out super.  P.S.--My boyfriend loves these, and he's pretty picky!

text:
This cookie was very cakey, and the taste reminded me of pumpkin pie. I covered the cookies in pecans and chopped cranberries before baking them, which made them even better! These were a bit too sweet for me (even without the icing), so I think I'll cut back on the sugar next time. I've been thinking about adding 1 cup applesauce instead of pumpkin puree and some ginger to make apple ginger cakes. I'll definately make this recipe, or some variation thereof, a lot in the future!

Very very good pumpkin spice cookies!  I don't use icing. text:
** 12/12/09** I made these again this year to give away, this time I did something a little different, I had a Clementine sitting on the counter and started zesting it right into the batter, not knowing what it would taste like, OMG it added a spice to it that made it even better!! Im sure an orange would be fine I just happen to have the clementine on hand! This is an awesome cookie to begin with but the orange zest just added the kick I was looking for!!**

This is the best and easiest cookie to make, everyone likes them, HOWEVER they are VERY BAD for my hips, the only thing I changed on this recipe is the glaze, instead of making the glaze I just sprinkeled powder sugar on top once they were compelely cool.
thank you for sharing this recipe.

text:
Not bad!  I omitted the icing for the sake of time, and for stacking purposes, since I always make double batches and send them to our jobs.  The flavor was slightly gingerbread-ish.  I did sprinkle light cinnamon-sugar over the tops before baking, and added my kitchen sink... the bottom of a box of raisins, the same with a bag of pulverized walnuts, and 1 cup (dbl batch) of mini-chocolate chips.  My friend appropriately re-named them "Pumpkin Muffies" and you get more of what you expect when you bite in with this name.  Won't be a regular for me, but probably will make once each season!  Thanks for the submission!

This recipe received unanimous "yum" votes in our house. (When I try a new recipe, we all vote "yum" or "yuck".  Recipes which receive unanimous "yuck" votes get ceremonially burned.) FABULOUS!! I was looking for a cake-like pumpkin cookie recipe like the one my mom used to make and this one turned out even better (I think!). My mom's used a cinnamon frosting, which I think is much tastier than the white icing included with this recipe, though (just make a white butter frosting with powdered sugar and vanilla and add some ground cinnamom -- yum!). You must try this recipe -- it's terrific. The cookies also freeze very well.

text:
Wonderful cookie. My recipe turned out a bit soft, although I doubled the recipe. Once baked
I iced them with a King Arthur "Glazing Sugar" instead of the ingredients listed for the glaze.
The Glazing Sugar made it a hard glaze. The cookies themselves were an easy recipe to make with
ingredients usually found in a bakers kitchen. The cookies were a big hit with my family and my daughters
class as well as we made them for her Thanksgiving feast. The end result cookie is a soft cookie. If you are
going to contain them, they will remain soft.

None
country:
None
text:
I just made a double batch of these. I docked one star for the ridiculous "number of servings listed." You'd have frustrating, nickel-sized cookielets if you tried to get 36 out of these. A DOUBLE batch made 24. So, that's 1 dozen *respectable* cookies per batch.

The only ingredient change I made was to use just 1 can of pumpkin for the 2 batches, since I wasn't about to open a whole other can to get the last 1/4 cup it called for. Each can has ~1 3/4 cups. I don't notice any troubles from that.

I also didn't bother with the glaze. I prefer all of my cookies unglazed. They're sweet enough as it is.

text:
I made this recipe gluten free, and they were perfect!!! I substituted the flour with Bob's Red Mill Gluten Free All Purpose Flour, as well as the baking powder with Bob' s Red Mill Gluten Free Baking Powder. I also dusted the cookies with brown sugar and cinnamon immediately after removing them from the oven. The texture of the cookies were light and cakey!! My guests could not tell they were gluten free!

Awesome! I’m not a huge “pumpkin everything” fan, but these had me coming back for more...and more, and more, and more! I love that they stay soft. The recipe yields a large amount, which is good because they’ll go very fast. I stuck to the recipe exactly minus one aesthetic tweek: I added 2 drops yellow and one drop red food coloring to the glaze, which came out a nice pale orange that screams “autumn”. Totally worth it!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are very tasty! I had 2 cups of pumpkin I need to use up, and it was almost midnight when I decided to make these cookies, so I had to make do with the ingredients I had. I used whole wheat flour, and since I was out of butter AND applesauce, (which I would usually use as a substitute), I used fat free vanilla greek yogurt. They came out more cake-like or pumpkin bread-like than typical cookies, due to the lack of fat in the ingredients, but they were really good. I put a healthy shake of cinnamon in the  glaze, too. I only needed to cook these for about 12 minutes, probably because I altered the recipe.

text:
Love these moist cake like cookies! I modified and used 1/2 cup light brown sugar and 1 cup white sugar and used the whole 15oz can of pumpkin to not waste anything. 

For the icing I found this ratio to work perfectly and if you wait until the icing sets you can stack the cookies on top.
3 Tbsp melted unsalted butter
3 Tbsp milk
1 tsp vanilla
2 cups powdered sugar

text:
This was quick and easy to make.  I used a cookie scoop for smooth, evenly sized cookies and lined my cookie sheet with a Silpat.  Based on other reviews, I added a bit more spices by not leveling off the spices in the measuring spoon.  The baked cookies were light in texture, with a wonderful lightly crisper bottom.  I frosted them with a brown sugar penuche frosting that was part of another pumpkin cookie recipe on this site.  The combo was so good!  My guests devoured them, and couldn't stop racing about how wonderful they were.  Not a crumb was left.  ??

text:
Wonderful cake-like cookies. I’ve made this three times for different events. I followed the recipe almost exactly the first two times (except once I had to substitute 1/2 tsp lemon juice + 1/4 tsp baking soda as I had no baking powder). The third time, I added a cup of chocolate chips. I also added a tsp of orange zest to the icing. I use an old-fashioned trigger ice cream scoop for uniform size and shape and did not flatten before baking. Everyone loved these with and without the variations.

userID:
4516242
Display Name:
brooklynn777
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were good when I made them last night but today they are fantastic! I did some swapping but otherwise stuck to the recipe. I used 3 t. pumpkin pie spice instead of the individual spices, out of personal preference. I also substituted half of the AP flour with whole wheat—yes, there’s a slight difference in texture but it’s not overt in this cake-like cookie.  Like other reviewers (& because I often do this swap in my baking), I substituted some of the white sugar, so I ended up using 3/4 c. white, 1/4 c. raw/turbinado sugar (just for the heck of it), and 1/2 c. light brown sugar. I saw a lot of comments about the cookie not being very sweet and I agree it’s much more subtle in sweetness, allowing the spices to be front and center. But the icing is very, very sweet so, if you plan to use this icing rather than a cream cheese icing as others have mentioned, you could probably reduce some of the sugar in the cookie. Believe me, with the icing it’s plenty sweet and, given my love of sweets and baked goods, that’s a rare thing for me to say. Also, don’t plan on packaging these up right away—even left on the counter barely covered since last night, the icing is still too soft to stack these cookies. They’re in a single layer in the freezer now to prep for storage & transport.

5

text:
I loved the way these turned out! At first when the batter was done I was a bit nervous as it was a bit liquid-y and nothing like I've ever made before. I really didn't want to waste it so I tried it out by taking a spoon of the batter and putting on the plate and putting in the microwave for a minute. I was super excited and it turned out great. So I then put them in the oven for about 16ish minutes. Took them out and made the glaze. I cut the glaze recipe in half as it seemed like a lot of glaze for about 25 cookies. I didn't use butter in the glaze and it turned about delish. I had everyone try them and they all loved them, even if its the middle of summer ! Thanks for the recipe- BlinkReagan

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4313019.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Everybody loved these! I made only a couple changes. I added about 1/4 cup of brown sugar to the cookie batter, and baked at 350 for only 12-13 mins as I scooped them slightly smaller than a tablespoon full onto the sheets. I didn’t flatten them either. I added pumpkin pie spice to the icing and found they were best to leave out overnight to dry before packing up into Xmas cardboard cookie boxes for gifts. I also suggest parchment paper between each layer when packaging. They were a huge hit at the office and with my family!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a new favorite recipe! I did make the following changes though: 2 cups of whole wheat flour + 1/2 c  all purpose, 1c brown sugar + 1/2 c white sugar, whole can of pumpkin instead of 1 c, 3 tsp of cinnamon, 1 tsp nutmeg, no cloves (didn't have any), 1 tsp ginger. They came out great! I like the whole wheat flour because it gives them a nice texture and is a little healthier. And using more brown sugar, they are not super sweet which is nice because the icing is. Next time I will try adding a bit more ginger and adding cinnamon to the glaze like someone else had suggested.

text:
REALLY nice and pillowly soft cookies.  I did half white sugar and half brown sugar and creamed the daylights out of the butter and sugar so they would turn out fluffy.  Next time I will add more spices as the flavor was pretty mild.  I had to cook these for 15 minutes.  My icing was took thick to drizzle so I nuked it for about 15 seconds and that did the trick.  Perfect icing too!

text:
I have made these cookies half a dozen times over the last two months. Everyone loves them. They've been requested for Thanksgiving even. I follow the recipe exactly, with the exception of glaze application - instead of drizzling with a fork, I dip the top of the cookie into the glaze and use the back of a butter knife to remove the excess.  They take exactly 15 minutes in my oven and I always have 3 dozen cookies. 
One of these times, I want to try using orange extract and orange juice in the glaze instead of milk and vanilla extract. 
Excellent recipe! Thank you for sharing!

text:
I love these cookies. I make them every year and they go over really  well. They are soft more cake like than cookie. I don’t recommend storing them in an airtight container as they have a lot of moisture. They are just the right amount of sweetness in my opinion. They are not too sweet and the spices give them a great flavor. I sprinkle powdered sugar on mine instead of  using the icing. I’ve made them for work dinners and family gatherings and there are never any leftovers.

text:
I was looking for something to give out for Halloween (along with popcorn balls) and found this recipe. The only departure I made from the recipe was to dunk the cookies into orange and black sprinkles after I had iced them. I was immensely pleased with the look of the finished product and loved the taste and texture of the cookies. I will most definitely be making them again, perhaps for Christmas with red and green sprinkles. My only problem was that the drizzle/frosting/icing was a little too sweet for my taste (although family members disagree), I will use less on each individual cookie next time.

text:
I am not a pumpkin lover but these cookies may have changed that! They were easy to make and storage wasn’t an issue because they didn’t last long enough. I tried them with the basic glaze which was great, but then I started to experiment. I had some Honey Pecan cream cheese spread and made icing out of that—wow! Then I tried the glaze with the maple flavor like another review suggested and that was also a winner. Finally, I added some fresh orange zest and juice to the glaze recipe—definitely my favorite!  These cookies will be in the rotation for a long time.

This recipe is so good that you don't even need to do all that for them to come out delicious..  It really is perfect!  Cakey texture, glaze hardens perfectly. region:

country:
None
text:
Instead of making the glaze as listed on the recipe, I made a slightly different one using brown sugar...it creates a caramel taste to it that blends well with the pumpkin...Penuche Frosting calls for 1/2 c. butter...1 c. dark brown sugar, 1/2 c. half and half or you can use milk as I did, a pinch of salt, 1 tsp. vanilla. You just heat the butter and add your brown sugar until its a rolling boil. Lower the heat and add the salt and powered sugar. You just have to be careful not to thicken it, but if you do, add a little hot water to thin the glaze out. It was positively "da bomb".

2625463
Display Name:
Danielle Harshenin

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5202891.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been using this site for years and FINALLY tried this recipe tonight (which happens to be the first day of Fall). I think my expectations were too high, as this recipe has been made by so many users and rated so highly. It's very good - just not as great as I was expecting. I see some other users have made "variations" by adding nuts or white chocolate chips, and switching to a cream cheese icing or maple glaze. I think those variations would be delish!! This is a "basic cookie" that could be very versatile. Without any icing the cookie itself would be too boring to eat. I made a double batch and followed the recipe (almost) exactly. Only change was to use 1/2-cup of brown sugar in place of some of the white. I also only added a dash of salt, but may add more next time for flavour. I also probably added about an extra 1/4-cup of pumpkin. The dough is very sticky and hard to "shape". I found using my fingers worked the best to slightly flatten/shape/smooth. The cookies do not flatten as they bake, they puff up. I baked in convection at 325 on light metal sheets for 13-minutes (perfect). For the icing: I added 1/2-tsp of cinnamon and ended up using 5-tbsp of milk to get the right consistency. I only made a single batch of the icing and it was plenty for the double batch with some to spare. Next time I will definitley try a cream cheese frosting. **Update** these were very tasty (as is) the next morning after cooling! I took the advice of another reviewer and didn't store

text:
These are perfectly delicious. Despite reading several reviews saying they weren't sweet enough I still decided to cut the sugar by 1/4 cup. That was only because I was hoping to avoid the sticky cake-like consistency.  That was the only change and these are perfect!   They are soft but have a slight crunch to the outside. The glaze adds just a nice additional sweetness to the cookie.  I could also imagine mixing in a handful of small chocolate chips instead of the glaze.  Nothing Else to add except these are a keeper.

text:
I tried this and I just made a few tweaks. so first of all the icing that you recommended would probably be a little too sweet. 
 so I really think you should try this: I used cream cheese frosting, the ingredients are: powdered sugar, a 5 ounce package of cream cheese, and water. mix that altogether for about two min. and tada! you have your cream cheese frosting. instead of drizzling the frosting on I used a spoon to dolip the frosting on it. and it was really good that way too. so anyway, I loved these cookies and I'm definitely going to make them again!

These cookies were absolutely delicious! They were more of a cake consistency, but I prefer my cookies soft, so they were very yummy! They are slightly bland, so maybe add more pumpkin and glaze. The glaze was a little sweet and I would suggest putting in more milk than the recipe calls for, but otherwise these cookies are awesome! If you like soft cookies and pumpkin, these are for you!  If you make them smaller, you can eat two without feeling guilty. Eat them warm with a glass of milk!

text:
I thought these turned out great! I did do part brown sugar for the white to make it a little denser. When I halved the recipe I still used a whole egg and just 3 tablespoons of butter. I also added a sprinkle of cinnamon to the glaze. Be sure you shape your cookies before popping them into the oven because they don't smooth or spread out much on their own. I also recommend baking for the entire 20 minutes since these are already pretty moist cookies

text:
I used this recipe but instead of making cookies I used it to make muffins. If you add about another 1/4th cup of milk you can use the recipe to make pumpkin muffins. I made no changes to the filling besides not using egg whites.

IF you make muffins cook them for 30 minutes at 330 degrees. the filling can be put on after they are cooled. Like frosting!

text:
A couple of things to note. The cookie is very cake like. Some people like, it others don't, so just note it. 

The cookie is very good but the simple glaze for this cookie just doesn't do enough. Instead of just doing a sugar glaze, I substituted out the milk and butter for orange juice and grand marnier. The orange flavor of the glaze gives its a nice, sharp contrast to the sweet, spicy cookie.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I advise you to not substitute the eggs and butter with pumpkin, unless you're vegan and you really want to try this recipe. The first time I made this, I cut down on the sugar but everything else remained unchanged. I didn't want to make icing for it to lessen the calories. They were really nice and cake-like, but the spice taste was really strong.  I made the second batch with the recommended measurements of sugar, however the spice was still way too strong and I messed up by substituting the eggs and butter with 3/4 cups additional pumpkin puree. They ended up really bread-like, but that's my own fault. I'm going to cut down on the cloves and cinnamon next time since I really like nutmeg,  plus I'll actually put icing, so hopefully they taste perfect!

These came out perfect.  I was a little skeptical of the dough at first because it was more moist and sticky than "normal" cookie dough.  I substituted 1 1/2 cups white sugar for 1 cup white sugar and 1/2 cup light brown sugar (for no particular reason other than the desire for a more molasses taste).   I also added cinnamon to the frosting.   The cookies definitely need a sweet frosting. This recipe made 3 dozen cookies for me.

i was looking for a recipe to use pumpkin and this looked so yummy so couldn't resist trying.  After reading all the reviews and getting everyone's ideas, i made these "cake" cookies exactly as the recipe called for but just increased the amount of pumpkin puree.  The batter was very sticky. Turned out really yummy and everybody loved them especially my daughter who runs at the sight of anything veggie related. definitely will be making again but will make sure i bake them for the 20 mins next time.

I made these cookies tonight for the first time and they were delicious.  I took some tips from the previous reviews (1 cup of white sugar and half a cup of light brown sugar and also added more than a cup of the canned pumpkin) .  The cookies are cake like and the spices really come out and taste great.  I took the cookies to work and everyone raved about them.  Would definitely make again!!!

Wonderful fall cookie - tastes like a mini bite of pumpkin pie! I am in Colorado so made a few adjustments for high altitude.  I added 1/4c. flour and 2T. water (added to the flour) I also decreased the sugar by just a bit - scant. The cookies turned out nice and fluffy! I also used cream cheese frosting instead of the glaze.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A sweet bread cookie lacking flavor without the glaze. I suggest pumpkin to 1 1/4 - 1 1/2 C, 1 C brown sugar, 3/4 C white sugar, measure your tsp of vanilla over the bowl without sweating overflow, 2 Tbspn and 2 dashes of cinnamon for me, but my cinnamon is old. 12 minutes of baking, or the cookie is ultra sticky, and let them sit for a while before closing them inside a container! It will let them dry a smidge so they don't become a tacky mess. I like topping them with a 60% cocoa drizzle, but they're tasty without, too.

text:
So the first 8 cookies I made I followed the recipe to the T (minus the frosting), but I didn't like them all that much. They just weren't 'cookie' enough for me. So I added another 1/2 cup of pumpkin purée, 1 1/2 teaspoons of pumpkin spice, and about 1/3 cup of sugar. Perfect! I baked them for about 13 minutes and they turned out big and soft. I also used my own frosting recipe (1/2 stick melted butter, half box of confectioners sugar and a few splashes of milk as I mixed.) my 2 year old daughter loves them!

text:
This is one of my all time favorite cookie recipes. Super easy to make and such a great result! The only modification I make is to do 1 cup sugar and sub the other 1/2 cup for light brown sugar. I usually skip the icing and add mini chocolate chips. If you want them a little more gooey, just cook them a little less time. Not my preference, but that's how my husband likes them! They generally don't last more than a few days, but seriously are so good!

text:
Love, love, love these cookies.  I can't understand the complaints about the texture - there's a wide spectrum of  textures  among different cookies, and this one just leans a little "cakey," but definitely doesn't detract from being a satisfying cookie.  I agree with other reviewers that 12 minutes is about perfect for baking these.  I followed the recipe other than swapping out 1/2 cup of white sugar for brown, but used a different frosting (a caramel frosting recipe I found elsewhere).   My husband doesn't think they'll make it to Christmas, which is only 3 days away!  I'll be making these again and again.

text:
I doubled this recipe and used some brown sugar in place of white sugar, and followed the rest of the recipe exactly. The batter is SO sticky to work with! I found it hard to put them on the cookie sheets and flatten because it just stuck to the spoon or my fingers. So mine turned out lumpy, prickly and not very pretty. I baked them for 15 minutes. I think they tasted good, but there's not a ton of flavour.. I feel like next time I want to add more pumpkin, as I also found mine a bit dry. Maybe I won't bake them as long either. Overall, good, but I will make some changes next time.

I made these and followed the recipe exactly, which I rarely do.  They were a big hit at Thanksgiving and everyone loved them!  Moist and not too sweet, they are great with a cup of coffee. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Have made these a few times now. For a much bolder spice flavor I add an extra teaspoon of cinnamon, as well as doubling the clove and nutmeg (so 3tsp cinnamon, 1tsp each clove and nutmeg). I also add cinnamon to the icing (start with 1/2tsp and add more to taste). The result is a powerfully flavored spiced pumpkin cookie that tastes like pumpkin pie in a cake-cookie form! I don't mess with anything else in the recipe. Cookies come out cake-like in consistency.

text:
These were wonderful!  They were very spongy, almost like a pumpkin sponge cake.  Everyone loved them!

I made a few changes as suggested by other reviewers, plus some of my own:   

1)  Used 1 cup white sugar, 1/2 cup brown sugar,  
2) I used 3 tsps of pumpkin pie spice,
3) I added cinnamon to the icing.  

I found that one batch of icing was not enough.  Not sure if I overiced  :) , but either way, I made 1.5 total icing batches.

I've been making a similar version of these recipe for years and it's always a hit. Here are my modifications:
-1c sugar (instead of 1.5c)
-Half the icing ingredients, with 1tbp brown sugar OR mix in mini chocolate chips
-Optional: 1can of pumpkin puree instead of 1cup. I did this once by accident and they turned out great.

text:
YUM! These are better than anything you can get in a corner bakery.  I added 1/2 tsp of ginger to the batter, and 1/2 tsp cinnamon to the glaze.  I added a little extra milk to the glaze to make it runny and dipped the tops of the cookies into it instead of drizzeling.  I think it's prettier that way and you get a nice thin layer of glaze in every bite.

I love these cookies. They're like little bite sized pumpkin breads. I cut back on the cloves cause I'm not a huge fan of the flavor and use half white sugar, half brown as someone else suggested. I always use orange juice in the glaze. It just adds an extra flavor. If someone doesn't like sweet, you can leave out the icing and I still think they're yummy. Awesome recipe.

text:
These were indeed wonderful and spicy!  I spread the icing on generously and I added chocolate chips (1 cup, but next time I'll add 1.5 cup) and chopped walnuts (approx 1/2 c).  I highly recommend adding the chocolate chips and walnuts.  I could not stop eating these cookies!  The spices come through strong for a very unique cookie experience.  I have some overripe bananas, I think I'm going to try this with banana now, but maybe with just the cinnamon and nutmeg.  Enjoy!!
UPDATE:  I made it with the bananas today (a scant 1 cup of mashed) + 1.5 cup choc. chips and 1/2 c walnuts, omitted the clove and 1/2 tsp of the cinnamon.  DELISH!!  Didn't need the icing as the banana and choc. chips made it plenty sweet.  SO MOIST AND SOFT, like little muffins.

text:
I followed this recipe and just made one change. Instead of 1.5 cups of white sugar, I used 1 cup of white and .5 cups of brown. The cookies turned out well and there was no need to flatten them using my cookie scoop. I found a bag of pumpkin flavored chips in Aldi and melted them in the microwave to use as a topping, and then added a spider web on top with melted chocolate. They look really nice and store bought. This was my first time doing the spider web and I used a tooth pick to achieve the look.

text:
I don't know about this cookie. Based on the reviews, I was expecting something awesome but that's not a what I got. I think that the recipe needs to specify the size (oz.) of pumpkin puree because all my grocery stores only carry the large can that makes 2 pies. Since the recipe calls for 1 can, I used 1 can but this made a cake batter consistency "dough". I tightened it up with flour but I'm not happy with the results.
  The flavor and texture was like a pumpkin pie-made into a cake-made into a cookie. I love pumpkin pie so I loved the flavor of the cookies.

text:
After reading all of the reviews, I knew these had to be amazing! I was a bit surprised by how sticky the dough was, only because I've never baked anything pumpkin-related but my gosh, it was SO hard not to eat all of them. (Which I would have gotten sick but ya'know). They're THAT good. I only added a bit more sugar and pumpkin puree to give it a more deep flavor. And let me tell you they're SO moist! If you're looking for the perfect soft cookie, this recipe's a winner. I made 2 batches of these cookies and gave them to all my family. My Mom ate it with whip cream and said it tasted like pumpkin pie. I think it tastes like pumpkin bread to be honest. :)  And for first timers, make sure you put plenty of flour on them when rolling the dough into a ball. The end result will have a bit of flour on them but you can't even taste the flour so its all good. : ) My Dad bought 4 cans of pumpkin puree today, so I think I'm going to make 4 more batches lol. I have no idea who's going to eat them but I'm sure any cookie lover would love to eat these! I would put 10 stars if I could.

text:
These were great cookies! Going by some of the reviews, I did change the 1 1/2 cups of white sugar to 1 cup of white and 1/2 cup of brown. Also, I added 1 1/2 tsp of cinnamon and 1 1/2 tsp of pumpkin pie spice instead of the spices listed. I also used all 15 ounces of the pumpkin purée and did not add extra flour to make up for the extra pumpkin. The cookies came out cakey for me, I love the texture. I baked them for 12 minuets! Aaaaand I used cream cheese icing instead of the icing recipe, my family loved them with the icing, I prefer them without it! Will make again!

text:
I made these cookies for a bake sale and altered it slightly by doubling the pumpkin and adding ginger to the spices.  At high altitude baking generally takes a little more of a skilled touch to adjust for the rise and to keep the moisture consistent.  I made no specific adjustments for altitude and these were the first cookies that I have made that came out perfect and were the first items sold out at the sale.  This recipe made me shine and as an amateur baker I will keep this as my go-to recipe for all desserts go forward.

text:
They are still warm in my kitchen, and they are really good!  I followed the recipe to the letter and although most of the time I find things I would change; that was not the case with this.  I used a small 12oz can of pumpkin since the recipe did not state what size to use.  

I did make some of them into cookies on a sheet, and some in small cupcake pans to see how they would turn out of it.  With a little baking spray, they came right out and they are a perfect size.  The icing is sweet so you might want to adjust how much you put on it.  

These are moist without being sticky and if you like pumpkin, you will enjoy these.

text:
I made these cookies LACTOSE FREE and healthier for my family by substituting Earth Balance Sticks for the butter and almond milk for the dairy milk.  They were fabulous!  I also adjusted it slightly for my personal taste by using the whole can of pumpkin, adding 1 tsp. pumpkin pie spice, 1/2 c. chopped dried cherries, and 1/2 c. chopped pecans to the mix and 1 tsp. cinnamon to the icing.  They were done at 14 minutes.  Great recipe that can be modified easily!

text:
These are a great Fall cookie.  I went with the suggestion of 3/4 cup white sugar and 3/4 cup brown.  I was tempted to use the whole can of pumpkin (because what do you do with the rest?) especially since other reviewers had success doing that.  Instead I just threw in a few extra slugs and threw out the rest of the can.  The cookies were just fine, so next time I'll be braver and put the whole can in there!  Instead of glaze, I used cream cheese frosting (4 oz cream cheese, 1/4 cup butter, 1 tsp vanilla and enough powdered sugar to stiffen it up, about 2 cups).

text:
This recipe is tasty and easy to make. I did follow some suggestions. 2 eggs, mostly brown sugar, increased amount pumpkin, a touch of maple syrup, and increased amount of spices. I also put in some raisins, which were great. These were like pumpkin bread in cookie form in my opinion. I think they look cute. I brought them to a Christmas cookie party.  People didn't gravitate towards them like they did to showier cookies like pretty frosted sugar cookies. Oh well, more for me and my family! Had some for breakfast with coffee. Yum. I used Pam spray on the cookie sheets and they came off easily. This is an easy way to make a heck of a lot of tasty cookies.

text:
These are moist, flavorful and a new favorite of mine!  I am making an extra batch to take to the deactivation event Dec 22 for the 235th MP Co arriving home from Afghanistan just in time for Christmas!

This recipe is easy to assemble and delicious!  My husband had one lone surviving pumpkin from his garden.  I found this recipe and decided to give it a try last night.

At first, I thought I was going to have a mess on my hands when I used semi-soft-melted butter...but I added a bit more flour - 1-2 Tbsp for the consistency I thought would be right. (Our homegrown pumpkin may have had more moisture in it than canned.)  It wasn't necessary to press the dough and I had exactly 3 dozen cookies.  I iced them this morning, but tried them without the icing last night and they were every bit as good!  Oh, I did add cinnamon chips to half the batch and they were just as good!

I made these cookies to try then out before Thanksgiving and everyone, including my mother who is not a pumpkin person, loved them! They're a soft, cakey cookie that actually tastes like fall. I did however make a few changes- I used 1/2 cup of brown sugar and only 1 cup of white sugar and since i didn't have cloves, I replaced all the spices with Penzey's pumpkin pie spice. They came out great, but do really taste better with the icing than without.

This was a great recipe for using my leftover canned pumpkin after making pumpkin pie, as I had everything I needed in the pantry already. I substituted brown sugar instead of white, as it makes the cookies softer which I love. I also added 1/2 teaspoon of ginger. For the icing I added a couple of drops of orange essence. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies are fantastic. I used the entire 15 oz. can of pumpkin (1 3/4 cups), substituted half the white sugar for brown sugar, and added 1/2 cup of raisins.

I left the icing off some -- they taste more like muffin tops without the icing, which in my opinion is totally fine. The icing adds sweetness and transforms them into more of a dessert item.

As another user mentioned, don't store these cookies as a sealed container. I left them in an open bag in the fridge to keep the icing from getting gummy, and that helped the cookies from going to much as well.

country:
None
text:
I don't like cloves so I substituted with ginger, and I baked mine for less time as the first dozen burned. I live at a high altitude and I think that may have been my issue. Also, it doesn't say whether to grease the cookie sheets prior to baking. DON'T grease them, you can use parchment if you wish, or a well seasoned sheet works just fine. I also found if you make the icing a bit thicker you can use a spoon right after they come out of the oven and it melts beautifully over the whole cookie without leaving too much icing behind.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are great cookies. I made a few changes after reading some of the other reviews. For the spices, I replaced the cloves, nutmeg and cinnamon with pumpkin pie spice. I also added an additional 1/8 teaspoon of cinnamon and nutmeg. For the flour, I replaced 1/2 the white flour with wheat to make a denser texture. And for the frosting I added cinnamon. I suggest you cut the frosting portions in half if you like your cookies lightly Frosted.  These cookies taste even better the second day! The spices really come to full flavor. I had these with my morning coffee. Delicious!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were sooo good! And really easy. The only things I did differently was 1/2 cup of brown sugar in place of 1/2 cup white sugar, 2.5 tsp pumpkin pie spice in place of the cinnamon, nutmeg and cloves, and used 18% table cream in the icing instead of milk. I was contemplating making cream cheese icing but the icing in the recipe was perfect, so glad I didn't! 

You have to smooth out the batter because all the peaks will stay. I found wetting my fingers with cold water and smoothing them out worked better than a spoon. 

I brought them to a potluck and people who don't usually like pumpkin-flavoured things liked these.

These cookies are amazing! The first time I made them I brought them to Sunday Dinner and there was none leftover. My husband insists they are the best cookies he's ever eaten. I will likely make these year round. The texture is incredible - so moist and soft. I stick to the recipe almost exactly, I simply add 1/2 tsp of ground ginger as well. If you are debating making these cookies stop and just do it! You won't have any regrets.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super good cookies. Made a double batch with a 15oz can of pumpkin. I used a medium cookie scoop and got 42 cookies that were the size of an average cookie. I then made some smaller ones and got 58 out of that batch. I baked the smaller cookies for 12 min. and the larger ones for 15 min. I didn't double the batch of frosting, but I did add a 1/4 tsp. of cinnamon and about 3tbsp. of whipped cream cheese. I also added some chopped pecans to the tops. These cookies are great. I think next time I will add 1/2 tsp. of cinnamon to the frosting to give it a little more flavor. I may also try subbing orange juice for the milk, and maybe another batch with maple flavor. yummm, what a great fall recipe.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are my favorite cookies ever!! So moist and delicious. I wasn't much of a pumpkin fan before these, but now I totally am! I converted many people at work too... 3 dozen were gone in less than 5 minutes! I usually just add the entire can of pumpkin instead of 1 cup, and use about 3 generous teaspoons of pumpkin pie spice instead of all the individual spices. Other than that, I pretty much follow the recipe as is. And to make them more 'visually appealing' I put the batter into a piping bag and pipe them onto the baking sheet since they don't really change shape much during the baking process... and I also put the frosting into a ziplock bag, cut off the tip then spiral the icing onto the cookies once they've cooled down. Makes them very pretty!!

text:
I just finished making these... I never wrote a review before. I don't even care that much for pumpkin. These are absolutely divine!. I pretty much followed the recipe with the exception of using a bit less flour maybe 2.25 cups instead of 2.5 cups. I only used 1/4 tsp of cloves and increased the cinnamon just a bit to 2.25 tsp. I also used 1 cup of white sugar and 3/4 cup brown sugar. I also used a whole can of pumpkin. I baked for 12 minutes. Within the 3 minutes of writing this review my girls have pretty much devoured the first batch. Oh for the glaze, I ended up using 5 tablespoons of milk and everything else was the same. Delicious!!

text:
These are amazing & delicious like everyone says. I had friends & family agree & ask/beg/demand for more to be made! On my 2nd time, I decided to make the glaze maple by adding maple extract rather than vanilla to the glaze ingredients. This was a wise & delicious choice--it tasted just like maple candy (New England-er here)! Then I dusted the glaze, whilst sticky, with cinnamon which, for me, helped balance the sweetness wonderfully as I do find most confectioner sugar glazes too sweet for my teeth. But these cookies are a definite winner & permanent member of my recipe box!

I also used fresh pureed pumpkin instead of canned. I baked the first batch for 15 minutes and the second for 10 minutes. the ones that baked for the shorter time were more dense. I personally, liked the ones that baked longer, although my 4 yr. old liked them both ways.. a keeper that I will definatly be making plenty more times.

I use carmel icing - 1 cup dark brown sugar, 1/2 cup cream, 1 1/2 tsp vanilla, 6 Tbsp butter, 2 cups powdered sugar.  Combine all but powdered sugar in sauce pan, bring to a boil and cook for 2 min. remove from heat and add p sugar, stir till smooth.

text:
I doubled the recipe so I could use an entire 15 oz. can of pumpkin.  I used white whole wheat flour, 2 cups brown sugar and one cup white sugar, and Earth Balance instead of butter.  Based on other reviewers' suggestions, I baked the first batch for 12 minutes...but they were just a tad underdone, so I baked the rest for 13 minutes.  These are fabulous!  I don't think I'll even make the icing because they are so good by themselves, so why add unnecessary calories?

userID:
3290685
Display Name:
Janie
isPro:
False

0

0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
61
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These pumpkin cookies were amazing!  Make sure cookies are completely cooled before storing. If stacking cookies in container, I recommend adding a piece of parchment (wax) paper between each layer. 
I made a few substitutions:
2 1/2 cups all-purpose flour => 1 cup whole wheat flour & 1-1/2 cup all-purpose flour, 1-1/2 cup white sugar => 3/4 cup white sugar & 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1 teaspoon baking soda => 1-1/4 tsp baking soda, 1 can pumpkin puree => 1 cup fresh pumpkin-baked at 350 degrees for 75 min & then cooled. Optional additions: 
1/2 cup raisins or 1/2 cup mini chocolate chips or 1/2 cup dried cranberries with orange peel. Hard to resist. You won't be disappointed!  :)

None
text:
Amazing!  I make these at least twice every fall.  I've never had a cookie have such a fluffy cake-like texture.  They're just sweet enough with the glaze so as not to be overpowering.  Whenever I bring these cookies to a gathering, there are never any leftovers!  Another user said don't store them in an air-tight container and I agree!  There is so much moisture in these cookies that they will turn to mush. A foil-covered plate will store them just fine.

Display Name:
Rich V.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies are DELICIOUS! I am known for my cookies, and when I served these up at a dinner party recently, EVERYBODY raved about how they were the best cookies ever! A couple of people even said 'These are like pumpkin pie donuts!'. I will suggest two things: Allow the batter to chill overnight. The batter is a little sticky and soft, and the cookies will come out too flat. When completely chilled, it is more easily scooped and rolled into balls which can then be flattened out slightly. And as for the icing, I suggest that, rather than drizzling it, place the entire cookie upside down into the bowl of drizzle. Then lift it back out and allow any excess drizzle to fall off (or help it off with a butter knife, or by scraping the cookie on the side of the icing bowl). The cookies are more visually appealing with the white frosting, and they just taste better.

text:
This recipe was exactly what I was looking for to sell at our town's Pumpkinfest. I topped it off with an orange powdered sugar glaze and pumpkin shaped candy corns. I used a large scoop for my cookies and got 17. I baked them for 15 minutes in a 375 oven. They spread just fine without any pressing down. They don't stack well since they're so soft, but they do freeze well once they're baked, then you can stack them.

We loved these!  I made them for a road trip...the kids had half of them eaten right after they came out of the oven.  I froze the rest so we could take them on our trip later in the week.  My husband, who hates pumpkin, devoured them the first day.  :) They did freeze well, although I did not try the icing; I sprinkled them with cinnamon sugar right out of the oven instead (we're not big icing fans).  I will be making these again and again.  My kids now ask for them first.  Thanks for sharing the recipe.  Super yum!

text:
Awesome!  I used closer to 1 t of the cloves & allspice & added in ~1 t of ginger for a stronger pumpkin spice taste.  I also used 1/2 c of white whole wheat flour which you couldn't even taste - could easily bump it up and use more whole wheat flour in this recipe!  I put a cream cheese frosting on top which was way better than a simple glaze would have been.  (Combine 1 8 oz brick reduced fat cream cheese w/ 1/4 cup butter, 2 cups powdered sugar).

text:
Light, spicy and not too sweet. Very tasty and easy to make. I did as some others suggested, using 1/2 cup brown sugar and 1 cup granulated sugar. Also added some cinnamon and just a touch of nutmeg to the icing. I used a cookie scoop to put the the cookies on the baking sheet (which I covered with parchment) because the dough is a little sticky and not so firm. The cooking time was right on for me. I will make these yummy fall cookies all year round. Thanks for sharing.

I LOVE these cookies!  One of my co-workers brought them to work about three years ago and I have been making them ever since.  I just made a batch of these, substituting things to make them dairy free, egg free and gluten free (Earth Balance butter, Hemp milk, Ener-G egg replacer and gluten free flour).  Surprisingly, they still turned out perfect!  I do add a teaspoon of cinnamon to the icing ingredients, though, it compliments the cookies!  Enjoy!

text:
These were perfect to take to a party. My family tried them fresh out of the oven and recommended that I not ice them since they were already so sweet. Other than that, I followed the recipe as written. I left them out cooling overnight on the counter. They were moist and had a mild gingerbread flavor that both the kids and adults loved. I didn't shape the dough in any way, just plopped it in Tbs. on the cookie sheet. They spread out beautifully. I've never made such perfectly shaped cookies before!

userID:
758559
Display Name:
busybee
isPro:

followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
74
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/159197.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these cookies last night for my teen daughters to take to a special lunch with their friends.  I can't comment on how well they store because all the cookies are gone!  Everyone loved them.  They have a soft, cake-like texture, aren't too sweet, and have just the right amount of spiciness.  Be prepared for a very soft dough - almost like a thick muffin batter.  Be sure to cool them thoroughly before frosting or else the heat from the cookies will turn the opaque white icing into a translucent glaze.  After frosting them, I let them sit overnight before stacking and covering them.  The icing was not sticky at all this morning and they packed and transported nicely.  The icing recipe made about twice as much as I needed - and I frosted the tops completely instead of drizzling the icing on.  I guess I'll have to make another batch of these delicious cookies to use up the extra icing!
Review:

OK, these are awesome! The only changes I made were I used 2 cups light brown instead of 1 1/2 cups white sugar. Previous posters are correct about covering these...they are so moist that they turn to mush if you seal them. They need air. I made them about 9 hours prior to serving them and they are perfect.

text:
This cookie is very good.  As is, its not too sweet so it could be eaten at breakfast time with a hot beverage. I did exchange 1/2 cup of white sugar for 1/2 cup of brown sugar, which made the creaming process a little long. I used a whole teaspoon of cinnamon and pumpkin spice rather than the other stuff.  If you do want it sweeter add more sugar.  
  I did not care for the icing at all.  I think the cookie is perfect without the icing. If you have a favorite icing recipe then use that instead of the one provide.  In addition, If you do use an icing keep the sugar the same amount or you will have a really really sweet cookie!

Display Name:
Brody's Ma

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies are definitely addicting! I would have given it 5 stars, however, I found the dough consistency was too hard to work with if you wanted a visually appealing cookie as the end result. The only alterations I made were to add 1/4 more cup of pumpkin. Next time I might reduce the the flour by 1/2 cup and increase the eggs to 2. I also added about 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon to the icing like other reviewers suggested and it was perfect! A suggestion to those of you who like the drizzled icing look- pour the icing in a ziploc baggie, and snip a tiny corner off. Drizzle away! (P.S.-if you don't want the drizzles to run together, definitely wait until the cookies have cooled completely!)

Exactly what I was going for!  They spread just enough and were done in 15 minutes.    I used to make these by adding pumpkin to a box of spice cake mix, but this way is better (butter!)  I altered the spices a little because I'm a little spice-crazy; I used 1 tsp ginger and 1/2 tsp allspice, and reduced the cinnamon to 1 1/2 tsp.

userID:
3750818
Display Name:
Garrett B.
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
86
favoritesCount:
265
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
They taste like wonderful little bites of pumpkin bread, they're so sweet and warm I simply love it. I do feel that the overly sweet / buttery taste of the glaze steals from the warm pumpkin taste. So next time I'll cut the glaze in half, so a third will have none, a third a ton, and a third just the slightest line.  I tried to use a stand mixer to cream the butter and sugar, but it didn't work too well, so next time I'll just skip the mixer and do it all by hand. Oh, and the glaze needed half the vanilla but more milk, you just had to sprinkle and check the consistency. And following a review I gave 5 shakes of cinnamon to the glaze and it was a fantastic idea.  15 minutes worked wonderfully, and using a cookie scooper was the best option to get exactly 36 that had a round top when cooked. And the scooper was a clean option since the dough is exceptionally sticky to the point that I considered refrigerating it for an hour (but the recipe didn't say to). I still haven't found a good way to flatten the dough once on the sheet. Anything used to flatten it sticks to the dough...  5 STARS!!!

Try sticking the dough in the freezer for fifteen or the fridge for an hour to make it less sticky perhaps.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-11-13T14:20:01.713
helpfulCount:
0

text:
Like reviewers stated this is a cake texture. If you are looking for a cookie texture this is not it.  But if you are OK with cake like "muffin" top texture this is it.  Tastes really good and will make again, but not if I want cookie texture.  Instead of the various seasoning I used pumpkin pie spice blend.  Be sure to wet fingers to help with flattening cookie.  For glaze I only needed half recipe.  Omitted butter and added pumpkin spice to it as well.  Really good...Enjoy Update: Next day actually like them less.  Don't think I'll make again.

text:
These cookies are DELICIOUS - the only reason I gave it four stars is because I think they're much better with the addition of nuts and/or chocolate chips. I have also done a version with cranberries and those are fantastic as well. Be careful sealing them in a container - they are very moist cookies. I make these every fall for parties and they go very quickly. I prefer them without the glaze. This recipe also makes a TON of cookies, especially if you use a spoon to distribute the batter.

userID:
2146352
Display Name:
Shannon B.
isPro:

0
madeRecipesCount:
12
favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took this to a fall themed baby shower and a church event. I've never had so many people tell me how good something was. I think it would be great as written but I used 1/2 cp of brown sugar for 1/2 cp of the white and slightly changed the spices - 1 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 1/2 tsp nutmeg (no change there) and just 1/4 tsp of cloves because they can be overwhelming. The glaze was wonderful and gave a perfect finish. For those who had issues with this recipe - I fluff then measure flour, leveling the cup with a knife, beat the butter and sugar for a couple of minutes, then also beat the mixture for a couple of minutes after adding the egg, pumpkin and vanilla. This gave it a perfect texture. I flattened and smoothed the cookies before baking for a nicer looking final result.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2206610.jpg
city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I decided to make these cookies to use fresh left over pumpkin puree.  I followed the recipe to the letter and like a fellow reviewer above added 1 teaspoon of all spice, cinnamon and nutmeg. When I dropped them by the tablespoon unto the cookie sheet and baked them, they came out bumpy and unattractive--like rock cakes! But the taste was incredible! Moist, delicious and supurb! I also placed the dough in the fridge for 2 hours to firm the dough up. I give it four stars only because I was disappointed in the appearence of my cookies, but this was probably down to my dropping the cookies by tablespoons and not flattening them out! But it was impossible to flatten as drop cookie dough is sticky!

text:
I really liked this recipe.  I found that it did need the icing and I did add some cinnamon to the icing since a reviewer had suggested that.  I didn't have cloves so I used 1.5 tsp of cinnamon and 1.5 tsp of pumpkin pie spice and I found the spice just perfect.  One word of advice, if you want to double this recipe do not make it all at once.  It's way too hard to mix after.  Just make one batch and then make another batch.  Other than that, these cookies are very tasty!  Thanks for the recipe!

region:

country:
None
text:
These cookies are a great pumpkin treat!  They are light and cake-like.  The only thing I did different was I added 1/2 tsp of Pumpkin Pie Spice to it, just to give it more of a pumpkin pie taste.  When they first came out of the oven, they didn't taste very sweet so I didn't think this recipe was a good one, but if you just let them sit for a while, even over night, the flavor is SO MUCH better.  I gave some to my neighbor and she said the same thing: they are even better the next day.  I will definitely be making these again!  Oh, and I dropped my cookies on the cookie sheet by the ice cream scoop-full and it made about 15 cookies.  They were way bigger than a normal cookie, but it's the perfect size for your pumpkin craving!

text:
Love this recipe but like other's I changed a few things myself....I used fresh pumpkin, 1 cup white sugar, 1/2 cup brown, pumpkin pie spice, cin. and cloves....I also used a caramel drizzle rather then the glaze....1/2 cup brown sugar, 1/8cup con. sugar, 4 caramel squares, 1/4 cup butter, bring to a boil and drizzle away...It makes for a very rich, gooey, cake like cookie....Lots of fun!

I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE these cookies!  I've been making them for about 3 years now.  Very moist, fragrant, and irresistible. They make the house smell delicious.  I always make double batches so I have enough to give to the girls at work - they always ask for (actually, they demand) them!  My 1-year-old son loves these, but he eats everything.  My almost-4-year-old niece, who is the pickiest eater on the planet, loves these too!  It makes me feel like a super-aunt for sneaking something healthy into her diet.  She especially loves them with the icing, which she likes to tint with food coloring.  **Note, a couple of times when I made these I didn't have ground cloves so I left it out,  and they were still yummy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh my goodness were these DELICIOUS!!!  I used homemade pumpkin puree and, because of previous experience, I knew it would be a little more watery than canned pumpkin, so I used about 1/3 cup more flour to compensate.  The cookies came out beautifully after 16 minutes.  I immediately took the cookies off the baking tray (but still on the tinfoil I baked them on) to let them cool and finish setting.  I only made about 1/2 the glaze and drizzled it on half the cookies because the flavor of the cookies was so wonderful that the added sweetness just wasn't necessary for my taste.  This is definitely a moist, cake-like cookie with a wonderful, subtle pumpkin-pie flavor!!!  Great with coffee!

text:
EXCELLENT!  I've made these three weeks in a row, and the people at work LOVE them.  My two suggestions:  Instead of making cookies, make one huge bar cookie and cut up.  And, and add soaked raisins.  I did this the last time I made these, and they got even better reviews then the cookies themselves.  I made a double batch (with 1 cup soaked raisins) and baked all the dough in a 11x17 jelly roll pan.  I waited for it to cool, cut them with a pizza cutter, and frosted them individually, like I did the cookies.  They were a HUGE hit at work!
