text:
these cookies were great.  they were a hit too.  everyone wants more.  i dont get everyone saying they had no flavor.  u MUST taste as u make the batter.  i added a 1/4 more pumpkin and i put cinnamon in the icing.  the were delicious.  i think if they came out flavorless for some that it is easy to rectify if u adjust the flavorings.  also they were just fine 2 days later.  i left some uncovered and some in ziploc and they were both fine.  the ones left uncovered were just a little harder on the outside, but still very cakey inside.  try this recipe if u love pumpkin!

None
text:
I thought these came out very good. I followed the recipe to the letter. I saw several complaints that the batter was too sticky and hard to manage. I used a 1 tablespoon cookie drop which I sprayed with nonstick cooking spray to drop the cookies. If you don't have a cookie drop, now is the time to buy one. I also used parchment paper. I didn't flatten the dropped cookies as they spread just enough while baking. You can experiment with the icing. Good recipe.

Stick to the recipe! Maybe a little more spice is needed, but the flour and pumpkin amounts are perfect. For the first batch, i followed the recipe exactly and the texture was great. For the second batch, I tried to get a little more flavor by adding more pumpkin (1/4C) and just enough flour to hold it together. They turned out awful! Too dense and not cakelike at all.  I was amazed at the difference between the two batches.

text:
I made these today and they were great!  I followed a few of the other reviewers' suggestion and substituted half of the white sugar with brown sugar.  I also did not make the icing because it sounded very sweet, and that's not what I wanted. I flattened the cookies with the bottom of a glass dipped in sugar.  The cookies are very cakey, moist, and delicious.  I'm sure they will be a hit for Halloween.

country:
None
text:
I'm giving this 4 stars for one reason: this is a very finicky cookie. I made exactly as stated the first time, and found them dry and not all that flavorful. Since I love pumpkin, I decided to try again. I shortened the baking time, used part brown sugar as someone suggested and added some cloves to the icing, and just those 3 changes helped immensely. I found that these are very touchy cookies. 1 minute is the difference between mushy and overdone, so trying to find that magic window in those 60 seconds can be a real pain.

text:
Great cookies! So moist, sweet and delicious.  They are muffin-top like, but I've never had a pumpkin cookie that wasn't.  I did add an extra 1/2 cup of pumpkin, and also substituted 1 1/2 cups almond flour & 1 cup whole wheat flour for the all purpose flour.  Also added raisins and walnuts to half the batch.  They are delish!  I love them, my kids love them too.  I may decrease the sugar next time around, because with the frosting on top they are a bit sweet for my taste.  But overall YUM!  Saving in my faves.

text:
Very nice!  Definitely needed the icing (I used a cream cheese icing that I enjoy).  Making the cookies was a little challenging for me.  The first sheet was one tablespoon, slightly flattened.  I thought they were too small.  The next sheet was 3x the amount, flattened kindasorta (smeared around) to about a 1/2 inch think round mass, and baked 12 minutes.  Much better, and much prettier - especially topped with the icing.  Tasty, but not so sure I'll make again.  I needed to use a can of puree I opened to make the chocolate chip muffins from this site.

text:
This recipe is everything it promises to be and more!  The consistency really is just like a muffin top, but somehow even more delicious than that sounds. 

I made the recipe exactly as written except I added almost a whole can of pumpkin (about 1 and 1/3 cups) and I used 1.5 tsp Cinnamon and 1.5 tsp pumpkin pie spice for the spices.

I also experimented with adding milk chocolate chips in one batch, the result: Yummy!!!

I will definitely use this recipe again, I love the texture of these cookies.

text:
I would give more than 5 stars if I could.  These cake-like ccokies are an amazing little treat, especially warm!!
I added a little more cinnamon (as usual), but other than that, followed recipe to a 'T'.  To ice the cookies, I used a gallon size ziplock bag, and put it in a cup folding the bag down the outside of the cup.  I then filled the cup/bag with the icing.  I cut a small slit in the corner of the bag, and viola, a homemade icing bag!!  You will love these if you like anything pumpkin!!
Kudos to the creator!!

Display Name:
Flannery
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/67375.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are really great Gina! I've made them three times now. The first was as written (except I used whole wheat pastry flour -- I always do), the second time I doubled all the spices for a more intense flavor, and the third time I simply used pumpkin pie spice mix in lieu of the single spices. All three ways are delicous, not too sweet and wonderfully flavored. I didn't need to flatten the cookies, they did it all their own in the oven. I found I like them the best ever-so-slightly underdone...they cool to a lovely soft texture. The icing is an excellent addition...the cookies are great on their own but the icing really makes them special. Nice work, Gina!

text:
Generally it takes very little for me to love a desert so long as it has pumpkin! Pumpkin bread, pumpkin pancakes, pumpkin cake, but these were not fantastic.  USE A CREAM CHEESE BASED ICING! They taste much better. I use a recipe similar to this, but use pumpkin pie spice (about 2 tsp), about 1 1/4 cup pumpkin and 1 3/4 cup sugar. I even add a small amount of strained pumpkin to the icing(a few tb)

text:
Very good, but only 4 stars since I had to modify to our tastes...  Thanks to the review who said these would come out with the look and texture of a muffin top, because that gave me the idea to top these with sugar in the raw by pressing the dough with a buttered/sugared glass.  Cookies are very cake-like and soft.  I did use a whole 15 oz can of pumpkin and just added a little flour because we like more pumpkin flavor in our pumpkin cookies... go figure!  Added craisins and white chocolate chips to some and it was very tasty.  My 4 year old has been munching on them this afternoon, and he loved helping to make them.  Thanks for sharing the recipe!

userID:
3181985
Display Name:
Morning Coffee

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/124314.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If there was a four and a half star option, that'd be my final rating. These were very, very good, yet not what I was expecting. Just a warning so you won't be surprised while making; the dough when ready is like bread dough, almost yeast like. Once the cookie is baked, the texture is still more of a pumpkin bread than a cookie. As a result of this, you will have to more than slightly flatten the rounded tablespoonfuls before putting into the oven. They will rise, but NOT spread. So much to the point that next time I'll consider baking them while in perfect balls, and dipping them into the icing to make pumpkin donut holes!
I used Splenda to make the dough sugar free, and mine required no more than 10 minutes in the oven on light-colored cookie sheets. 
Add food coloring to your glaze for the fall and Christmas seasons.
Overall, great recipe and worth your time this season. Though I would consider re-naming these to Iced Pumpkin Bread Cookies.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-10-29T17:46:17.65
helpfulCount:
0

text:
These cookies are fantastic!  I love anything pumpkin, and these are the best pumpkin cookies I've had.  The spicy aroma fills and warms the house on a cool autumn day.  I made them pretty much as the recipe states, except that I added about 1/2 cup more pumpkin (I just wanted to use up what I had left), and I added chopped pecans and dried cranberries.  After reading the reviews first, I also added a little cinnamon to the glaze and that was very good.  I flattened the first batch with a sugar coated glass bottom.  The second batch, I didn't flatten.  We decided we liked them much better flattened, and we liked that little extra sugar on the tops.  They baked perfectly for me in 15 minutes.  I like them with and without icing.  Either way is delicious.

text:
The best cookies I've ever had! I used a real pumpkin for the pumpkin puree (cut it in half, baked face-down at 375 for 1.5 hours), and it worked beautifully w/ a little over a cup of the flesh.
Like other reviewers, I added 1 c. white sugar and 1/2 c. of brown sugar instead of all white sugar, and only made half of the frosting--which was more than enough, as the cookies are so delicious that they only need a little bit of the frosting. Thank you so much for posting this delicious recipe! I know that I will make these cookies often!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe once I made a few changes.  My family doesn't like pumpkin, so I use a cup of homemade sweet potato pie filling instead, and used a half cup of dark brown sugar, after cutting back the white sugar to a cup.  I also wanted a cookie that would be easy to pack for lunches, so I decided instead of the icing, to roll the cookies in a mixture of raw sugar and cinnamon.  The raw sugar gives the cookies a nice crunch, and the brown sugar makes them less like cake.  Excellent!

text:
These were pretty good, but nothing fantastic.  I love pumpkin and spice, so I thought I'd REALLY like these.  Don't get me wrong.  They WERE good, just not great.  My co-workers liked them (I made these a while ago and am just now reviewing - :o) ).  Actually, I made them for my bf and I, and didn't care for them enough (to have several dozen laying around my house), so I took them to the office to share.  I did really like the soft cake-like texture (yummy!).  I prepared the recipe for penuche frosting (pumpkin cookies with penuche frosting from Suzanne Stull on this site) instead of the basic icing recipe and liked it very much.  These remind me of a similar cookie sold at a local bakery here in the Chicago burbs.  Thanks for the recipe!

These are great - if you like pumpkin - they are moist and tasty.  I didn't flatten them out though - I use a scoop similar to an ice cream scoop but smaller to scoop out cookie batter, so it is consistent and all the cookies are the same size for even cooking results.  These were nice and fluffy, so I am glad I didn't flatten them at all.

These are delicious! Yes, they are cake-like texture but it still taste great! I didn't have any ground cloves, so I substituted ground allspice and it turned out fine. They were right that you shouldn't put it in an alltight container because the glaze didn't harden and started to melt off the cookies. Just keep the covers off until glaze are harden.

text:
I followed the recipe to the letter, and found that I'm just not a fan of these cookies. They puff up a LOT in the oven and are more like a very dry cake than a cookie. The inside, though soft, is very dry and when you start to chew it, becomes a gluey blob in your mouth....it's sort of like eating raw cookie dough. My family loved them anyway, though I can't see why!

userID:
1735212
Display Name:
GourmetShea
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe definately dosn't need any tweaking, but becuase I like to experiment I have made these several ways. My favorite variation is as follows: I substituted 1/2 C white flour for 1/2 C. wheat flour, a little extra cinnamon and vanilla, I didn't have ground cloves on hand so I thought it would be fun to use Pumpkin Pie Spice in place (approx. 1 1/2 tsp), as always I used low fat margarine which didn't compromise the texture or taste at all, and in place of the pumpkin puree I used canned easy pumpkin pie mix. (Because the pie mix is slightly thinner than canned pumpkin I added flour to a desirable consistency). Finally I mixed in almost an entire bag of milk chocolate chips.  The cookie consistency was perfect (slightly cakey/slightly dense) and the taste was amazing! I got rave reviews all around and the empty plate in minutes was proof that they were delicious (some guest took a couple cookies for the drive home)! Trust me, these variations do not make the cookie too sweet or spicy, it's full of flavor and just right.
Review:
Rating:
3

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow! If everything was this easy and good, I'd cook more often! I used 1/2 cup brown sugar and 1 cup white, and a whole (15 oz) can of Libby's 100% pure pumpkin, just because I didn't want the leftover pumpkin. The cookies are moist and cake-like this way, more like a muffin, but absolutely delicious. With a whole can of pumpkin, I got 44 cookies out of the recipe. I also used finely chopped walnuts in the icing. They bake quick; cool quick; disappear quick, and are soft enough for my 18 month old granddaughter to eat, as she only has a few teeth.  Good source of vitamins in the pumpkin. We love them!!
Soooo easy!!!!!!!

text:
This was our second year making these yummy cookies!  We first tried these last Christmas.   This year my 8 year old son picked these to make as his contribution to Thanksgiving dinner.  He added a little extra pumpkin. He also put semi-sweet chocolate chips to half the mix.  Once baked and cooled he iced some, and left some plain.  He dipped the whole top of the cookie in per one reveiwers suggestion.  Great tip!  He added chopped walnuts on some of the iced cookies.  The cookies were devoured at our Thanksgiving potluck and everyone raved about them!   They couldn't believe an 8 yr old made them!
We will be making these many more times this Holiday season!

text:
Update: I have to admit to being a little disconcerted by a review that says they took this recipe and gave it to a restaurant to sell....and that they sell out. I don't mind posting recipes for home use but I would hope if a recipe got posted and used for sale that credit would be given!

Awesome every time I try it. My husband took them to work once and the employees are always asking when he will bring them next. When I have not had something on hand I have modified a little, but mostly use the recipe as is. Example was I was out of cloves but had apple pie spice exchanged. Also have used pumpkin pie filling (in a can, more sugar) instead of just pumpkin but didn't change anything else. Excellent.

country:

text:
These cookies turned out really bland.  After making the first batch and tasting them, I added more cinnamon, nutmeg, cloves, and hazlenut syrup to the second batch to add more spice.  This helped, but still too bland for my taste buds.  Next time, I'm going to really watch how much pumpkin puree I add.  I think if I had added the exact 1 cup of pumpkin puree, the cookies would of turned out a lot better!!
